headline: COVID Has Killed About As Many Americans As The 1918-19 Flu
summary: COVID-19 has now killed about as many Americans as the 1918-19 Spanish flu pandemic did ‚Äî approximately 675,000.
bodytext: (AP) ‚Äî  COVID-19 has now killed about as many Americans as the 1918-19 Spanish flu pandemic did ‚Äî approximately 675,000. The U.S. population a century ago was just one-third of what it is today, meaning the flu cut a much bigger, more lethal swath through the country. But the COVID-19 crisis is by any measure a colossal tragedy in its own right, especially given the incredible advances in scientific knowledge since then and the failure to take maximum advantage of the vaccines available this time. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúBig pockets of American society ‚Äî and, worse, their leaders ‚Äî have thrown this away,‚Äù medical historian Dr. Howard Markel of the University of Michigan said of the opportunity to vaccinate everyone eligible by now. Like the Spanish flu, the coronavirus may never entirely disappear from our midst. Instead, scientists hope it becomes a mild seasonal bug as human immunity strengthens through vaccination and repeated infection. That could take time. ‚ÄúWe hope it will be like getting a cold, but there‚Äôs no guarantee,‚Äù said Emory University biologist Rustom Antia, who suggests an optimistic scenario in which this could happen over a few years. For now, the pandemic still has the United States and other parts of the world firmly in its jaws. While the delta-fueled surge in infections may have peaked, U.S. deaths are running at over 1,900 a day on average, the highest level since early March, and the country‚Äôs overall toll topped 675,000 Monday, according to the count kept by Johns Hopkins University, though the real number is believed to be higher. Winter may bring a new surge, with the University of Washington‚Äôs influential model projecting an additional 100,000 or so Americans will die of COVID-19 by Jan. 1, which would bring the overall U.S. toll to 776,000. The 1918-19 influenza pandemic killed 50 million victims globally at a time when the world had one-quarter the population it does now. Global deaths from COVID-19 now stand at more than 4.6 million. The Spanish flu‚Äôs U.S. death toll is a rough guess, given the incomplete records of the era and the poor scientific understanding of what caused the illness. The 675,000 figure comes from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The ebbing of COVID-19 could happen if the virus progressively weakens as it mutates and more and more humans‚Äô immune systems learn to attack it. Vaccination and surviving infection are the main ways the immune system improves. Breast-fed infants also gain some immunity from their mothers. Under that optimistic scenario, schoolchildren would get mild illness that trains their immune systems. As they grow up, the children would carry the immune response memory, so that when they are old and vulnerable, the coronavirus would be no more dangerous than cold viruses. The same goes for today‚Äôs vaccinated teens: Their immune systems would get stronger through the shots and mild infections. ‚ÄúWe will all get infected,‚Äù Antia predicted. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs important is whether the infections are severe.‚Äù Something similar happened with the H1N1 flu virus, the culprit in the 1918-19 pandemic. It encountered too many people who were immune, and it also eventually weakened through mutation. H1N1 still circulates today, but immunity acquired through infection and vaccination has triumphed. Getting an annual flu shot now protects against H1N1 and several other strains of flu. To be sure, flu kills between 12,000 and 61,000 Americans each year, but on average, it is a seasonal problem and a manageable one. Before COVID-19, the 1918-19 flu was universally considered the worst pandemic disease in human history. Whether the current scourge ultimately proves deadlier is unclear. In many ways, the 1918-19 flu ‚Äî which was wrongly named Spanish flu because it first received widespread news coverage in Spain ‚Äî was worse. Spread by the mobility of World War I, it killed young, healthy adults in vast numbers. No vaccine existed to slow it, and there were no antibiotics to treat secondary bacterial infections. And, of course, the world was much smaller. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Yet jet travel and mass migrations threaten to increase the toll of the current pandemic. Much of the world is unvaccinated. And the coronavirus has been full of surprises. Markel said he is continually astounded by the magnitude of the disruption the pandemic has brought to the planet. ‚ÄúI was gobsmacked by the size of the quarantines‚Äù the Chinese government undertook initially, Markel said, ‚Äúand I‚Äôve since been gob-gob-gob-smacked to the nth degree.‚Äù The lagging pace of U.S. vaccinations is the latest source of his astonishment. Just under 64% of the U.S. population has received as least one dose of the vaccine, with state rates ranging from a high of approximately 77% in Vermont and Massachusetts to lows around 46% to 49% in Idaho, Wyoming, West Virginia and Mississippi. Globally, about 43% of the population has received at least one dose, according to Our World in Data, with some African countries just beginning to give their first shots. ‚ÄúWe know that all pandemics come to an end,‚Äù said Dr. Jeremy Brown, director of emergency care research at the National Institutes of Health, who wrote a book on influenza. ‚ÄúThey can do terrible things while they‚Äôre raging.‚Äù COVID-19 could have been far less lethal in the U.S. if more people had gotten vaccinated faster, ‚Äúand we still have an opportunity to turn it around,‚Äù Brown said. ‚ÄúWe often lose sight of how lucky we are to take these things for granted.‚Äù The current vaccines work extremely well in preventing severe disease and death from the variants of the virus that have emerged so far. It will be crucial for scientists to make sure the ever-mutating virus hasn‚Äôt changed enough to evade vaccines or to cause severe illness in unvaccinated children, Antia said. If the virus changes significantly, a new vaccine using the technology behind the Pfizer and Moderna shots could be produced in 110 days, a Pfizer executive said Wednesday. The company is studying whether annual shots with the current vaccine will be required to keep immunity high. One plus: The coronavirus mutates at a slower pace than flu viruses, making it a more stable target for vaccination, said Ann Marie Kimball, a retired University of Washington professor of epidemiology. So, will the current pandemic unseat the 1918-19 flu pandemic as the worst in human history? ‚ÄúYou‚Äôd like to say no. We have a lot more infection control, a lot more ability to support people who are sick. We have modern medicine,‚Äù Kimball said. ‚ÄúBut we have a lot more people and a lot more mobility. ‚Ä¶ The fear is eventually a new strain gets around a particular vaccine target.‚Äù To those unvaccinated individuals who are counting on infection rather than vaccination for immune protection, Kimball said, ‚ÄúThe trouble is, you have to survive infection to acquire the immunity.‚Äù It‚Äôs easier, she said, to go to the drugstore and get a shot. ___ AP Health Writer Tom Murphy in Indianapolis contributed to this report. ___ The Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute‚Äôs Department of Science Education. The AP is solely responsible for all content. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Chevy Chase Man Charged With Wire Fraud Related To A Scheme To Steal $750K From A Non-Profit Organization
summary: Officials said 70-year Brian McQuade has been charged with wire fraud related to a scheme to steal $750,000 from a non-profit organization providing services to military veterans.
bodytext: GREENBELT, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Chevy Chase man is facing federal charges for allegedly posing as an investment advisor to steal nearly $800,000 from a non-profit organization that provides services for wounded veterans. Officials said 70-year Brian McQuade has been charged with wire fraud related to a scheme to steal $750,000 from a non-profit organization providing services to military veterans. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured According to the indictment, from June 2018 until Aug. 2021, McQuade¬†perpetrated a fraud scheme to obtain money from a non-profit organization. Officials said McQuade allegedly held himself out as an investment advisor to clients falsely telling clients that he would manage investment accounts on their behalf. He would instead misappropriate the funds provided by clients for his personal use. The indictment also alleges that McQuade stated that he worked as an investment advisor through an entity called Columbia Financial Advisors, LLP. He has not been affiliated with the accounting firm since at least 2015. He also represented to the Foundation that he was a licensed, registered investment advisor. McQuade allegedly told the Foundation that he would place the Foundation‚Äôs funds in a brokerage account that he would manage on behalf of the Foundation. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn On McQuade‚Äôs representations, the Foundation wired him $750,000 to invest on the Foundation‚Äôs behalf. The indictment states that McQuade never opened a brokerage account on behalf of the Foundation and he misappropriated the Foundation‚Äôs funds for his personal benefit, including transferring the funds to personal accounts and spending the money on restaurants, country club dues, luxury car payments, mortgages and other personal items. To conceal his misappropriation of the Foundation‚Äôs funds, McQuade allegedly continued to make misrepresentations to the Foundation about their investment‚Äîeven providing a fabricated account statement. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government If convicted, McQuade faces a maximum sentence of 20 years in federal prison for each of two counts of wire fraud.

headline: Parents React After Pfizer Announces Its COVID-19 Vaccine Is Safe For Children Between The Ages Of 5 to 11
summary: Pfizer said its COVID vaccine is safe and effective for children five to 11 years old.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Pfizer said its COVID vaccine is safe and effective for children five to 11 years old. The company said it will seek emergency use authorization and shots could be available as soon as Halloween. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured The news is a ray of hope for some parents with younger children. Children now account for one in four new cases and the Delta variant is sending more kids into the hospital than at any other time in this pandemic. ‚ÄúAnything that‚Äôs going to protect the children is always gonna be good news for me,‚Äù said Alexis, a parent of two children under the age of five. Pfizer used a smaller dose of the vaccine for children in their trial and found it to be ‚Äúsafe and well-tolerated, resulting in robust neutralizing antibody responses,‚Äù according to a statement from the company released Monday. Now, it will send their results to the FDA and other regulatory agencies for vaccine approval. ‚ÄúIf the FDA looks at this data and feels confident that it demonstrates this vaccine is safe and effective for children five to 11, you could have a vaccine within a month to 6 weeks,‚Äù said Dr. Scott Gottlieb, Former FDA Commissioner. And it‚Äôs not a moment too soon. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúSo many parents are waiting exactly for this news, especially given what‚Äôs happening now with the Delta variant‚Ä¶..there have been nearly half a million new cases in children in the last two weeks,‚Äù said Dr. Lena Wen, Public Health Professor at George Washington University. Many parents are now breathing a sigh of relief, like Wiley. ‚ÄúAnything is better than nothing,‚Äù he said, who plans to give his son the vaccine as soon as it becomes available. But for Christina, another parent, this trial doesn‚Äôt provide enough evidence. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not giving my kids the vaccine,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúBecause I don‚Äôt feel like it‚Äôs been fully tested.‚Äù The vaccine has already been approved for children 12 years old and older but as cases surge among younger children, Doctor Aziza Shad the Chair of Pediatrics at Children‚Äôs Hospital At Sinai said a vaccine will keep kids out of the hospital ‚ÄúHaving a vaccine that‚Äôs approved by the end of the year could prevent so many children from getting really sick from COVID in the early parts of next year,‚Äù said Dr. Shad. If the regulatory review with the FDA goes anything as it did for adults and older kids, which took about a month, millions of children could begin receiving their shot around Halloween. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government Despite that, it is unlikely children younger than five will be eligible for the vaccine before the end of the year.

headline: Students Sue To Block University System Of Maryland Vaccine Mandate
summary: A pair of Towson University students and a University of Baltimore employee are named as plaintiffs on the lawsuit -- suing the University System of Maryland. The suit asks the court to prevent the state‚Äôs public universities from punishing non-vaccinated students and employees.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A lawsuit over the University System of Maryland‚Äôs vaccine requirements was filed in federal court. Students filing in and out of the University of Baltimore law center are masked and vaxed. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a small sacrifice for a better quality of our education,‚Äù said Meriam Mossad, UB law student. A pair of Towson University students and a University of Maryland Law School employee are named as plaintiffs on the lawsuit ‚Äî suing the University System of Maryland. The suit asks the court to prevent the state‚Äôs public universities from punishing non-vaccinated students and employees. ‚ÄúI would anticipate that we‚Äôre going to see lots of lawsuits,‚Äù said Dr. Dan Salmon. Dr. Dan Salmon is cautious about advocating for mandates but the Johns Hopkins‚Äô Director of The Institute For Vaccine Safety said mandates should follow good safety data and supply. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs well justified from a scientific standpoint. Mandates have a long history of being effective and strong support from a legal perspective,‚Äù said Dr. Salmon. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúI consulted with my own doctor. I listened to some of the doctors like Dr. Fauci who know a lot more about this than I do,‚Äù said John Cardozo, UB law student. The policy affects about 170,000 students across the system‚Äôs 15 institutions including tens of thousands of faculty and staff. ‚ÄúWe had that already. We just added another vaccine to the list. Even before covid, in order to enroll, you had to have certain vaccines,‚Äù said Mariana Garcia, college student. Towson‚Äôs COVID-19 code of student conduct calls for disenrolling non-vaccinated students beginning last week. One of those students claims he‚Äôs been placed on ‚Äúuniversity probation‚Äù is named as a plaintiff in that lawsuit. ‚ÄúThere is a need for that extra push. I think that by mandating if you take things away from people, they‚Äôll be more apt to comply,‚Äù said Paul Robinson, UB law student. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government The attorney for the plaintiffs was not available for comment today. A spokesperson for the University System of Maryland also had no comment.

headline: School Bus Driver Shortage Continues To Impact Maryland
summary: All across the United States, there's a shortage of school bus drivers. The issue is so severe, even the youngest riders notice it.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬†  All across the United States, there‚Äôs a shortage of school bus drivers. The issue is so severe, even the youngest riders notice it. Violett  Yang is an elementary student in Clarkesville, Md. In an interview with WJZ reporter Ava-joye Burnett, she said ‚ÄúEvery seat has like 2 to 3 people in it, and a lot of the times kindergartners are squeezing in one seat.‚Äù READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Violett‚Äôs ¬†mother said things have improved since the first¬†couple of days in the school year. ‚ÄúI feel like the first one or two days¬†was a huge mess. The bus delayed at the beginning and sometimes picked up the wrong kids,‚Äù says Wang. But¬†Wang¬†also said the district is doing the best they can. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre short of school bus drivers this is a fact, it‚Äôs like a risky job. I think during the pandemic it‚Äôs even harder to find qualified school bus drivers,‚Äù says Wang. In Howard County, some high schoolers get picked up at six in the morning then the same driver goes back for a second set of¬†high school¬†students. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúI‚Äôm extremely disappointed that we are picking up our high school students at 6 a.m.,‚Äù says Deb Jung, a member of the Howard County Council. ‚ÄúI am a very strong supporter of starting school later for our high school students. They are literally not awake.‚Äù CBS News reported that more than 50-percent of school districts in the United States said their driver shortage is ‚Äúsevere‚Äù or ‚Äúdesperate.‚Äù A quick Google search shows that several¬†Maryland¬†counties are hiring. And this weekend, MDOT MVA will have a ‚ÄúBus Drivers‚Äô Day‚Äù at select MVA locations to help expedite the licensing process. Click here for additional details. https://governor.maryland.gov/2021/09/17/governor-hogan-directs-mdot-mva-to-take-steps-to-expedite-driving-tests-and-credentials-for-school-bus-drivers/ Drivers are worried they‚Äôll be exposed to COVID-19.¬†There is no clearly reported correlation, but¬†Baltimore City¬†schools¬†say drivers call out often. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ‚ÄúWhen we have to call a family at seven o‚Äôclock, you‚Äôve already planned to go to work at eight a.m. and to say that the bus isn‚Äôt coming and they all quickly have to find another option to get their child to school and child care. That‚Äôs a huge problem,‚Äù says Dr. Lynette Washington, COO¬†of¬†Baltimore City Public Schools.

headline: Three Maryland Men Facing Federal Charges Related To $2.7M Unemployment Fraud Scheme
summary: A federal grand jury has returned an indictment charging three Maryland men on federal charges related to a scheme to receive more than $2.7 million in unemployment benefits.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A federal grand jury has returned an indictment charging three Maryland men on federal charges related to a scheme to receive more than $2.7 million in unemployment benefits. The three men charged were 34-year-old Gladstone Njokem of Hyattsville, 32-year-old Martin Tabe of Bowie and 31-year-old Sylvester Atekwane of Hyattsville. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured According to the 13-count indictment, from February 2020 through February 2021, Njokem, Tabe, Atekwane along with others impersonated victims in order to submit fraudulent UI claims.¬† To do this, the defendants obtained the personally identifiable information (PII) of victims. The defendants shared the PII amongst themselves and with others and used the victims‚Äô PII to submit fraudulent applications for UI benefits in Maryland, Michigan, and Tennessee. The applications contained false information like contact information, addresses, work availability and that they were newly unemployed. They used false physical addresses for the applications so that any money paid to them by the state would go to them and not the victims. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn The indictment also details that once the defendants received the unemployment debit cards, they made cash withdrawals and other transactions throughout Maryland. The indictment says that due to the conspiracy, Njokem, Tabe, Atekwane, and others caused at least 600 fraudulent UI claims to be submitted in Maryland, Michigan, Tennessee, and at least sixteen other states, resulting in more than 2.7 million dollars in actual losses. If convicted, the defendants face a maximum sentence of 20 years in federal prison for conspiracy to commit wire fraud and for each of the nine counts of wire fraud. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government The defendants each also face a mandatory sentence of two years in federal prison, consecutive to any other sentence imposed, for aggravated identity theft.

headline: Baltimore City Council Approves Emergency Security Deposit Relief Act, Awaits Mayor Signature
summary: The Baltimore City Council approved the Emergency Security Deposit Relief Act Monday. It now awaits the signature of Mayor Brandon Scott.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  The Baltimore City Council approved the Emergency Security Deposit Relief Act Monday. It now awaits the signature of Mayor Brandon Scott. The Emergency Security Relief Act was established for the Emergency Security Deposit Voucher Program ‚Äî which will provide each family with a security deposit for certain funding under the act. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured City Council President Nick Mosby released a statement following the approval: READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúWe know the ability to afford quality housing has only gotten more difficult during these long pandemic months. The Council‚Äôs action tonight is meant to ease the stress by providing renters in our city up to $2,000 toward their security deposit.   This legislation, sponsored by Council Vice President Sharon Green Middleton, is the final piece of the Council‚Äôs first major legislative package. These legislative solutions honor our commitment to ensuring residents have safe, stable and secure homes.   Introduced in January, I worked with my partners on the Council to confront housing insecurity from a number of angles. Two of the bills are now law.   First, we are helping to keep renters in their homes in the midst of the eviction crisis with an innovative approach. Despite a ban during the pandemic, landlords were denying renters the chance to renew their leases and kicking them out of their homes.    Under this law, sponsored by Councilman Tony Glover, landlords must give tenants a reason for not renewing their lease in writing ‚Äî other than failure to pay rent. These reasons must be limited to what lawyers call ‚Äújust cause.‚Äù That includes a significant breach of the lease or the landlord‚Äôs desire to renovate the property or move into it.   Another bill, also now law, sponsored by Councilman Robert Stokes, created a 10-day grace period for tenants to pay their rent before they incur late fees. Aside from guaranteeing more flexibility, this bill helps to make sure people who receive public assistance have actually received their benefits before they‚Äôre required to pay rent.   Your Council is also working hard to help our homeowners avoid tax sale, exercising our legislative oversight and making sure eligible residents are signed up for the Homeowners‚Äô Property Tax Credit that can reduce or eliminate their tax debt. Congratulations to Councilwoman Odette Ramos for her work on this issue.   While we await Mayor Brandon Scott‚Äôs signature on this final bill to provide relief in the form of security deposits, I want to applaud Vice President Middleton for her diligence in seeing this through. Landlords often require renters to pay a security deposit worth hundreds or thousands of dollars ‚Äî money that many in our city simply do not have. Our bill gives renters with the lowest incomes priority in accessing quality housing with this one-time payment.   The City Council is a team of problem-solvers working every day on behalf of Baltimore families. No one should be worried about where they‚Äôll live, especially during a global pandemic. Safe, secure and stable homes provide families the foundation they need to thrive.‚Äù¬† MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ¬†

headline: 31 People Shot In One Week In Baltimore; Mayor, Commissioner, State‚Äôs Attorney Announce Plan To Stop Violence
summary: Baltimore City‚Äôs mayor, police commissioner and state‚Äôs attorney met at New Shiloh Baptist Church in the heart of West Baltimore Monday to lay out a holistic violence reduction plan. They admit current strategies are not working.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Firefighters washed the blood from the 900 block of North Gilmor Street. The 26-year-old man shot multiple times there is one of more than 30 people gunned down in Baltimore City over the past week, and many across the city are fed up. Baltimore City‚Äôs mayor, police commissioner and state‚Äôs attorney met at New Shiloh Baptist Church in the heart of West Baltimore Monday to lay out a holistic violence reduction plan. They admit current strategies are not working.   State‚Äôs Attorney Marilyn Mosby talked about the crime fight; she defended her policy not to prosecute low-level offenses. Mosby also said post-pandemic ‚ÄúTo say it‚Äôs been a tumultuous time in Baltimore is an understatement.‚Äù  @wjz   pic.twitter.com/rRLMNIEK7X   ‚Äî Mike Hellgren (@HellgrenWJZ)  September 20, 2021 READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúPast public safety practices have failed to keep our communities safe from violence and harm. We cannot arrest our way out of a culture of violence,‚Äù Commissioner Michael Harrison said.   ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs GVRS Partner Meeting represents BPD‚Äôs commitment to a comprehensive approach to reducing gun violence. This strategy embodies a holistic & all-hands-on-deck response to not only breaking the cycle of violence, but to promote justice, community engagement & social service  pic.twitter.com/Z9Z6iV5xDc   ‚Äî Baltimore Police (@BaltimorePolice)  September 20, 2021 ‚ÄúThroughout my life, we have failed to keep communities safe and keep people alive. We must do better‚Äîand I do mean we. Zero tolerance was appalling and did not work. The drug war did not work. Trying to arrest our way out of these problems did not work,‚Äù Mayor Brandon Scott said. None of the officials answered questions and closed the meeting to reporters after their initial comments.   Top city leaders‚ÄîMayor Scott, State‚Äôs Attorney Mosby and Commissioner Harrison‚Äîare discussing violence reduction   @wjz   #Baltimore   pic.twitter.com/tQtAo61kNO   ‚Äî Mike Hellgren (@HellgrenWJZ)  September 20, 2021 ‚ÄúWhile we need the hammer of the justice system for violent offenses. We also know that we also need community outreach and services and programs to connect with people before they reach the justice system,‚Äù city State‚Äôs Attorney Marilyn Mosby said.   ‚ÄòThis Loss Is Ours As A City‚Äô Baltimore Hockey Team Mourns Two Young Members, Murdered In East Baltimore Shooting  https://t.co/TdlNMcRVfC   #Baltimore   @wjz   ‚Äî Mike Hellgren (@HellgrenWJZ)  September 16, 2021 The program they are launching is called The Group Violence Reduction Strategy, which brings city resources together with social services to address the causes of shootings and stop people from turning to violence.   Mark Conner coached Davon ‚ÄòPeanut‚Äô Barnes who died in a triple shooting Sunday on East Monument St. ‚ÄúSo many of the condolences start out with, ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre sorry for your loss,‚Äô but this loss belongs to the whole city.‚Äô‚Äù  @wjz   pic.twitter.com/5FC4eLRm1s   ‚Äî Mike Hellgren (@HellgrenWJZ)  September 16, 2021 READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn It is a strategy the city tried and failed at implementing twice before under Mayors Kurt Schmoke and Stephanie Rawlings Blake. ‚ÄúThere is a long road ahead. Things won‚Äôt be smooth,‚Äù Mayor Scott said. The mayor‚Äôs office and law enforcement will monitor the impact. They will watch the program over six months in the Western District and warn against expecting immediate results. One mother who lost her son to violence knows the heartache too well. She declined to give her name but told WJZ Investigator Mike Hellgren Baltimore is not safe. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm scared to go out and catch the bus and come home because I‚Äôve got to walk two blocks to get to the bus stop,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúA lot of people want to come forward but they‚Äôre afraid because they come after the witnesses.‚Äù Baltimore City officials cited  Oakland, California  as an example. They said Oakland reduced shootings by 20 percent over seven years with a similar program. But that city‚Äîlike Baltimore‚Äîis now seeing another surge in violence. City State‚Äôs Attorney Mosby said she has no plans to change her policy of not prosecuting minor offenses. She said the mayor and commissioner are in ‚Äúphilosophical agreement‚Äù with her.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ¬†

headline: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôve Been Here 37 Years‚Äô Jilly‚Äôs In Pikesville Reopens For Business
summary: A Pikesville landmark destroyed by fire has reopened for business.
bodytext: PIKESVILLE, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Pikesville landmark destroyed by fire has reopened for business. The grill is fired up even before Jilly‚Äôs officially opens for the day. Its owners Scott and Kathy Reich said it‚Äôs been a long time coming but well worth the wait. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been here 37 years and this is all we‚Äôve ever known is Pikesville,‚Äù said Scott. Almost 10 months ago now, the Pikesville icon was engulfed in flames. ‚ÄúWhen I showed up here and saw the building like that there‚Äôs no words,‚Äù Scott said. Police arrested and charged the man they believe intentionally set the fire that nearly¬†destroyed this small family-owned restaurant. ‚ÄúIt was just so devastating to see, yeah, long long day,‚Äù said Kathy. Ever since that day, Scott said their phones have been ringing off the hook. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúFrom day one, the question was are you coming back?‚Äù said Scott. Their Pikesville community answered the call, raising nearly $35,000 for the employees, donating the pictures and even the ravens pitched in a kind note and one-of-a-kind memorabilia. ‚ÄúRight then and there, we knew there was no way we could leave Pikesville with a hole and not have the community that supported us,‚Äù said Reich. Scott and Kathy decided to buy the building next door and expand and the original Jilly‚Äôs location was transformed into an outdoor patio. ‚ÄúBetween the two of us, our ideas came to life, and this is exactly, exactly what we wanted,‚Äù Reich added. But they wanted to keep elements of the old Jilly‚Äôs, add some new ones and pay homage to the first responders with whom they are forever indebted. ‚ÄúEven though Scott and I own this place, it‚Äôs still Pikesville‚Äôs Jilly‚Äôs,‚Äô said Kathy. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government On Oct. 28, one year since the fire, Jilly‚Äôs will host an all-day fundraiser to benefit the Pikesville volunteer fire company, which was one of several units to respond that day.

headline: Police Identify Suspect Accused Of Stealing Cruiser & Jumping Into The Harbor As 41-Year-Old Andre Kirby
summary: Police have identified the person who was arrested Saturday evening after crashing an allegedly stolen vehicle, jumping from the vehicle, fleeing, and then jumping into the Inner Harbor as 41-year-old Andre Kirby.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Police have identified the person who was arrested Saturday evening after crashing an allegedly stolen vehicle, jumping from the vehicle, fleeing, and then jumping into the Inner Harbor as  41-year-old Andre Kirby.¬† Around 7:30 p.m., officers tried to pull over a suspected stolen vehicle. The driver refused to stop, accelerated and hit several vehicles. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Police followed the driver at a safe distance until the suspect crashed the vehicle at East Patapsco Avenue and St. Victor Street. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn The suspect got out and ran. The officers chased on foot until the suspect got into a patrol vehicle. The suspect drove off and bailed out of the patrol vehicle at Fort Avenu before jumping into the harbor water, police said. headline: Stanford Infectious Disease Expert Sets Record Straight on Nicki Minaj‚Äôs COVID Vaccination Tweets
summary: Stanford Infectious Disease expert Dr. Anne Liu has been in the trenches, battling the COVID-19 pandemic since its earliest days. She's seen patients die and has grown weary of celebrities like rapper Micki Minaj spreading unsubstantiated rumors about the dangers of vaccinations.
bodytext: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS SF) ‚Äî Stanford Health Care‚Äôs Infectious Disease expert Dr. Anne Liu has been in the trenches, battling the COVID-19 pandemic since its earliest days. She‚Äôs seen patients die and has grown weary of celebrities like rapper Nicki Minaj spreading unsubstantiated rumors about the dangers of vaccinations. Minaj made headlines last week when she noted in a tweet to her more than 22.6 million followers that the Met Gala required attendees to be vaccinated, and that she wouldn‚Äôt get the shot until ‚ÄúI feel I‚Äôve done enough research.‚Äù READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured She later issued a tweet sharing an unverified story about a cousin‚Äôs friend in Trinidad. Minaj asserted the unidentified individual ‚Äúbecame impotent‚Äù and ‚Äúhis testicles became swollen‚Äù after receiving the shot. ‚ÄúThis is a tough topic,‚Äù Liu told CBSN Bay Area. ‚ÄúI have patients who have taken their time to get vaccinated and some of them eventually come around and some of them have died of COVID. When our unvaccinated patients died of COVID despite our best efforts to get them vaccinated, or to treat them even after they have gotten the infection, it‚Äôs really horrible.‚Äù READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúI blame the widespread lies and all the falsehoods and misinformation that people are fed. It‚Äôs very upsetting,‚Äù Liu added emotionally. ‚ÄúPeople who have huge audiences are on social media are casting doubts on topics that there is better information to be found on. The people we are seeing in the hospital with COVID are either unvaccinated or their immune systems are such that they cannot respond to the vaccine. And it is really devastating.‚Äù When it comes to Minaj‚Äôs fertility claims, Lui said the science simply doesn‚Äôt support them. ‚ÄúUp front, we have to say there are many causes of infertility and testicular swelling. The COVID vaccines are not on that list,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThere is still a lot to be discovered whether the COVID infection can actually affect your fertility. The jury is out on that. But there is some data on COVID infection actually affecting other sexual functions.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government When it comes to expectant mothers getting a vaccination, Liu said: ‚ÄúIt is never too early to get vaccinated for the protection of the pregnant person. Pregnant patients are at higher risk of worse outcomes of COVID infection. Infections also jeopardize the health of the fetus. The vaccines are safe and effective for them and their fetuses. If I were pregnant, I would have gotten vaccinated already and I tell my patients who are pregnant to please, please get vaccinated.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs A James Bond Movie For TV‚Äô: Missy Peregrym & Zeeko Zaki On Season 4 Premiere Of CBS‚Äô ‚ÄòFBI‚Äô & Epic Crossover Event
summary: Missy Peregrym & Zeeko Zaki preview a brand new season of "FBI" on CBS and share what it is like to play special agents on television.
bodytext: (CBS Local)‚Äì¬† ‚Äú FBI ‚Äù makes its season four premiere Tuesday night on CBS and it is an event you will not want to miss. The three part epic crossover event begins with ‚ÄúFBI‚Äù starring Missy Peregrym and Zeeko Zaki at 8pm EST/PST, followed by ‚Äú FBI: Most Wanted ‚Äù with Julian McMahon at 9pm EST/PST and then the first episode of a new series called ‚Äú FBI: International .‚Äù The franchise came from the mind of producer Dick Wolf, who is known for other smash hits like ‚ÄúLaw & Order,‚Äù & ‚ÄúChicago Fire.‚Äù CBS Local‚Äôs DJ Sixsmith chatted with Peregrym and Zaki about their journeys with this show, what people can expect on the first episode of season four and what they think about all the adulation their characters Maggie & Omar receive on social media. New episodes of ‚ÄúFBI,‚Äù ‚ÄúFBI: Most Wanted‚Äù and ‚ÄúFBI: International‚Äù will also be available next day on Paramount+. READ MORE:  Missy Peregrym On CBS' 'FBI' & Working With Dick Wolf ‚ÄúWhen Dick Wolf says he‚Äôs going to do something, he does it,‚Äù said Peregrym. ‚ÄúNothing is going to stop him and he had this idea even before we started filming. He always wanted to do three shows. Here we are premiering our fourth season and it feels great to be the OG. I‚Äôm really proud of it and we were able to launch this great vision and I think it‚Äôs going to be really fun tonight.‚Äù ‚ÄúI got the opportunity to film a James Bond movie for TV,‚Äù said Zaki. ‚ÄúI was really excited that Dick Wolf got the pen back out and wrote this alongside our showrunners for each of the shows. It‚Äôs a big testament to the team and to Dick and to dream as big as possible and he‚Äôll make it happen.‚Äù READ MORE:  ‚ÄòI Can‚Äôt Believe I Get To Be One Of The First Protagonist Arab Muslims‚Äô: Zeeko Zaki On CBS‚Äô ‚ÄòFBI‚Äô & Dick Wolf On the season four premiere of ‚ÄúFBI,‚Äù the team is called into action for an investigation when a young woman is killed on her way home from a lavish yacht party attended by some of the most influential people in the world. Both Peregrym and Zaki are excited that they have another season to grow their characters. ‚ÄúMy sister is coming back and we‚Äôll have some more family drama coming up, which I‚Äôm excited about‚Äù said Peregrym. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs really all I know so far and it‚Äôs really interesting working on a show where you have this many episodes in a short amount of time and it‚Äôs constantly churning stuff out. It‚Äôs last second when we find out what we are playing and that can be really fun. I‚Äôm a big believer in putting my head down and doing the work.‚Äù ‚ÄúSocial media supports the hell out of us and it is so nice because we work so hard,‚Äù said Zaki. ‚ÄúEvery time I read anything, it‚Äôs all positive. It feels good and hopefully we keep that going. We have the family dynamic and we might drop some bloopers later today of us making a TikTok video. You can see our dynamic. Every single person in our cast is great and the atmosphere is so good. We want to prove to the world that you can have on-camera and off-camera chemistry.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs A Well Oiled Machine‚Äô: ‚ÄòFBI: Most Wanted‚Äô Stars Kellan Lutz And Roxy Sternberg On Dick Wolf‚Äôs Latest Creation Watch the epic FBI crossover event with ‚ÄúFBI,‚Äù ‚ÄúFBI: Most Wanted‚Äù and ‚ÄúFBI: International‚Äù beginning at 8pm EST/PST on CBS and stream all three shows on Paramount+.

headline: Lawyer For 1 Of 3 Texas Women Charged In Carmine‚Äôs Brawl Says They Were Racially Discriminated Against
summary: The chaotic scene at the restaurant was captured on cellphone video. In the immediate aftermath, police charged the three women with assault.
bodytext: NEW YORK (CBSNewYork)  ‚Äî There are new details surrounding the violent brawl outside of  Carmine‚Äôs  in New York last week.   The three Texas women arrested  claim they were racially discriminated against, CBS New York‚Äôs Kevin Rincon reported Monday.   The chaos last week seemed to be over proof of vaccination at the door, but now a lawyer for one of the women involved says the brawl was triggered by a racial slur.   It took several people to put an end to the fighting captured on cellphone video.   READ MORE :¬† Caught On Video: Carmine‚Äôs Hostess Attacked After Asking Tourists For Proof Of Vaccination   In the immediate aftermath, police charged three women from Texas with assault.   Staff at the restaurant claimed the women became unruly when they were asked to show proof of vaccination.   But now, an attorney for one of the women says that‚Äôs not what happened.   ‚ÄúCarmine‚Äôs and this hostess, they are trying to hide behind this misplaced use of the vaccine policy to justify her racist and completely outrageous actions that day,‚Äù attorney Justin Moore said.   Moore, who represents Dr. Kaeita Rankin, said the hostess used a racial slur during their exchange.   ‚ÄúAnd we know this predicament wasn‚Äôt due to the vaccine. It was due to a poorly trained staff member at Carmine‚Äôs who doesn‚Äôt know how to deal with women of color,‚Äù Moore said.   Rankin was in the city with her niece, Tyonnie, and her assistant, Sally Lewis, on business.   ‚ÄúThey are working with a recording artist who was recording some songs in New York,‚Äù Moore said.   Carmine‚Äôs now says the women did show they were vaccinated.   In a statement the restaurant said, ‚ÄúThree female guests in the party who had shown proof of vaccination and been welcomed into the restaurant without issue then launched an entirely unprovoked, brutal attack on our hosts, one of whom continues to suffer from a concussion.‚Äù   Carmine‚Äôs said the brawl happened after some men in that same group failed to show their proof of vaccination, adding, ‚ÄúNone of the hosts ‚Äî all of whom are people of color ‚Äî uttered a racial slur.‚Äù   ‚ÄúNow they said that this woman was Asian-American, but we know there has been a long legacy of Asian hatred towards Black people in this country,‚Äù Moore said.   In the days after, Carmine‚Äôs has said it is grateful, ‚Äúfor all of the support from our community and the city, which has been incredibly touching for our staff.‚Äù   But it has been a different story for the three women.   ‚ÄúThe fact they‚Äôre being casted as folks who are anti-vaccine, and also being casted as ignorant and Black, which is what the prevailing narrative has been. It‚Äôs completely injurious to these women. On top of that, and to compound issues, they‚Äôve been receiving death threats as well,‚Äù Moore said.   The lawyer is calling for the charges to be dropped, which has driven some in protest and to call for Carmine‚Äôs to close.

headline: Maryland Ranks No. 7 Among Most Diverse States
summary: Maryland ranks among the top states in the nation when it comes to diversity, according to a recent study.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  Maryland ranks among the top states in the nation when it comes to diversity,  according to a recent study . The WalletHub study ranked the Old Line State at No. 7 among the most diverse states, trailing California, Texas, Hawaii, New Jersey, New York and New Mexico. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured On the flip side, the least diverse states were West Virginia, Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire and Montana. According to the personal finance website, researchers compared all 50 states based on a wide range of metrics, from diversity in economic factors such as household income and educational achievement to cultural factors including racial makeup and languages spoken. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn The highest possible score was 100, but even the most diverse state (California) fell well short of that with a total score of 70.64. Maryland wasn‚Äôt too far behind with a score of 68.64. Here‚Äôs a list of the top 10 most diverse states:   California   Texas   Hawaii   New Jersey   New York   New Mexico   Maryland   Florida   Nevada   Arizona   MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government A  detailed breakdown of the rankings  can be found on WalletHub.com.

headline: Man Shot In The Head, Killed In Southwest Baltimore Tuesday
summary: A man was shot and killed early Tuesday morning in southwest Baltimore, police said.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A man was shot and killed early Tuesday morning in southwest Baltimore, police said.   Officers responded around 2 a.m. to the 2500 block of Washington Avenue for a reported shooting, where they found a 27-year-old man shot in the head. Medics pronounced the victim dead on the scene.   There are no details yet on what led up to the shooting.   Anyone with information is urged to contact Baltimore Police Department¬† Homicide ¬†detectives at¬† 410-396-2100 .

headline: Weather Blog: Low Clouds, And Sticky
summary: Marty's Blog
bodytext: Hi Everyone! ¬† Did ya see the ‚ÄúHarvest Moon‚Äù rise last night. It was bright enough rising slightly after sunset that in many online pictures you could see the blue of the atmosphere. It was bright, bold, and quite proud. But sorry to say the forecast of low clouds tonight might block seeing that ‚ÄúLa Luna moment‚Äù tonight. headline: Ravens‚Äô Fourth-Down Dice Roll Typifies A More Aggressive NFL
summary: "It‚Äôs nice when it works and everybody loves it, but there is another side of that story sometimes.‚Äù
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ/AP) ‚Äî  Al Michaels and Cris Collinsworth all but exhorted John Harbaugh not to go for it on fourth-and-a-long-1 from his own 43. The Ravens were leading the Chiefs¬† 36-35¬† and the Sunday Night Football crew figured it foolhardy to risk giving Patrick Mahomes the ball on the wrong side of the 50 and a minute to go. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured But this is 2021, when conventional football wisdom has given way to a healthy heaping of analytics flavored with a dollop of hunch. The revenge of the nerds, if you will. No longer are notoriously risk-averse coaches viewing the 4 on the sideline down marker as a green light to automatically send out the punting team.   "GO FOR IT!   That's what you did tonight!"  pic.twitter.com/2WBqqhqTyL   ‚Äî Baltimore Ravens (@Ravens)  September 20, 2021 Just last week, NFL teams went for fourth-down conversions a whopping 52 times, the highest single-week total in league history. Twenty-five of those were successful. So, ‚Äúdon‚Äôt discount the possibility that you go for this,‚Äù Collinsworth suggested. ‚ÄúNo, you don‚Äôt,‚Äù retorted Michaels. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be one hell of a call, though.‚Äù It certainly was. While the seasoned broadcast duo was debating the matter, the camera caught Harbaugh hollering to get Lamar Jackson‚Äôs attention. Finally, he ripped off his headset and stepped onto the field. You could read his lips: ‚ÄúLamar, do you want to go for this?‚Äù Of course he did. Collinsworth and Michaels still weren‚Äôt convinced. ‚ÄúAnd Lamar Jackson is going back on the field and they are going for it,‚Äù Collinsworth said incredulously. ‚ÄúOr at least the hard count.‚Äù ‚ÄúRight,‚Äù Michaels said. ‚ÄúAt least line up.‚Äù ‚ÄúBut they have been picking up a yard at will all night long,‚Äù Collinsworth interjected on a night the Ravens had already run for 250 yards and three touchdowns. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got this monster offensive line. You‚Äôve got an extra offensive lineman in there.‚Äù READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúYou just have to make sure you don‚Äôt jump‚Äù offside, Michaels said, still sounding unconvinced. Jackson wasn‚Äôt trying to draw the Chiefs offside. He was trying to get the first down, and he took the shotgun snap 5 yards deep and sliced up the middle behind four big bodies for a 2-yard gain. ‚ÄúAnd Jackson will¬†GET THE FIRST DOWN!¬†‚Äù Michaels screamed as Harbaugh was hugged on the sideline. ‚ÄúAnd in effect end the game.‚Äù   The  #Ravens  go for it on fourth down and Lamar Jackson runs behind the entire Baltimore roster to win the football game üëè  #RavensFlock       pic.twitter.com/6OG3si2BV8   ‚Äî Billy Heyen (@BillyHeyen)  September 20, 2021 ‚ÄúThe guts of a sailor!‚Äù Collinsworth said. ‚ÄúHe made the toughest call a head coach has to make and look at him. He knows it. That decision just won the football game. They kick that thing back to Patrick Mahomes, who knows what happens? Four offensive linemen on the left side of the center. And Lamar Jackson with the game on the line says nobody‚Äôs touching it but me.‚Äù One kneel-down and the comeback from 11 points down in the fourth quarter was complete, thanks to two incredible plays, the go-ahead touchdown by a cartwheeling Jackson and linebacker Odafe Oweh‚Äôs forced fumble and recovery with 1:13 remaining that handed the sure-handed Clyde Edwards-Helaire his first career fumble. Jackson handed Mahomes his¬† first loss in September ¬†after 11 victories, sending the Chiefs into third place in the AFC West behind Denver and Las Vegas, both 2-0. ‚ÄúWhat a game,‚Äù Michaels said. ‚ÄúOne of the rare times the Ravens were a home underdog. And a crazy game ends the way it does with a fumble and then a fourth-down conversion. A beauty tonight.‚Äù ‚ÄúAre announcers allowed to clap?‚Äù asked Collinsworth. ‚ÄúI would like to clap for that game. That was something else.‚Äù In Week 2, there were 35 conversion attempts on fourth down, with 13 of them successful. The 44% success rate should entice even more fourth-down gambles. Of the 32 games in the books, only three have featured zero fourth-down tries ‚Äî the Cowboys-Buccaneers and Dolphins-Patriots games in opening weekend and the Texans-Browns game in Week 2. While none has been as pivotal as the Ravens‚Äô game-sealing dare, the Denver Broncos have converted all five of theirs through two games, including three in a Week 1 win over the Giants. Teams are more aggressive than they used to be, as evidenced by the 87 fourth-down conversion attempts so far. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve looked at it hard over the years. Everybody remembers the ones that worked,‚Äù Broncos coach Vic Fangio said last week. The ones that didn‚Äôt tend to stick in the minds of coaches. ‚ÄúThe greatest example I can give you is the Ravens two years ago were 14-2 in the regular season and they lost their playoff game,‚Äù Fangio said. ‚ÄúThey had a hell of a team. They were going for it on fourth down more than anybody. They have a quarterback that allows them to do more things, but in two of the three losses they had, going for it on fourth down, got stopped several times and it was a major factor in two of their losses, including the playoffs. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nice when it works and everybody loves it, but there is another side of that story sometimes.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)
