headline: Pediatric Cataracts: When Is Surgery Needed?
summary: Adults aren‚Äôt the only ones who get cataracts. They can develop in children, too.
bodytext: By Lifebridge Health Adults aren‚Äôt the only ones who get cataracts. They can develop in children, too. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Three out of 10,000 children have a cataract, according to the American Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus. ‚ÄúAge of presentation is variable. Some babies are born with cataracts. Other children develop cataracts at various points throughout childhood. The age of presentation depends on the cause of the cataract,‚Äù says Samantha Feldman, M.D., a pediatric ophthalmologist at the Krieger Eye Institute, a LifeBridge Health center. A cataract, whether in an adult or a child, is a clouding of the lens that can occur in one or both eyes. Pediatric cataracts can be idiopathic (meaning they can occur spontaneously without a known cause) or result from genetic disorders, infections, trauma or other systemic diseases. Cataracts can be large or small. The size often determines whether the cataract is visually significant. If the cataract is large, Feldman says, parents may notice a white spot in the pupil or a dim or white reflex on photos taken with flash. ‚ÄúIt is also possible for eye misalignment to develop due to the poor vision. However, poor vision may not be apparent in young kids, especially if only one eye is affected,‚Äù she adds. Although cataracts can cause blurry or cloudy vision, not all children will complain of a vision problem. This, in addition to parents sometimes missing abnormalities, is why it‚Äôs important for children to get routine examinations by their pediatrician. ‚ÄúPediatricians may note an abnormal red reflex in the newborn nursery or during a routine well-child check and refer the patient to be examined by a specialist,‚Äù Feldman says. ‚ÄúThe pediatrician‚Äôs office also performs vision screenings that can pick up on eye misalignment and poor vision.‚Äù READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Small cataracts that aren‚Äôt affecting the child‚Äôs vision should still be frequently monitored by a pediatric ophthalmologist. In some cases, glasses or patching may aid visual development in children with a cataract that‚Äôs tiny or off center and surgery can be delayed or even avoided, according to the American Association for Pediatric Ophthalmology and Strabismus. But once it‚Äôs apparent that a cataract is causing vision problems, it should be removed as soon as possible. Because children‚Äôs eyes and brains are still developing, a delay in removal could lead to lifelong visual impairment. It is especially urgent to remove a visually significant cataract that is present at birth. ‚ÄúSurgery may be required as early as four weeks of age,‚Äù Feldman says. Although cataract surgery performed by an experienced surgeon is generally considered safe, no surgical procedure is completely without risk. Some risks associated with pediatric cataract surgery include:   infection   bleeding   inflammation   retinal detachment   glaucoma   loss of vision   lack of improvement in vision or poor visual outcome due to amblyopia   the need for additional surgery   displacement of the intraocular lens (an artificial lens for the eye)   development of cloudiness in the visual axis   anesthesia complications   Depending on the age of the child, an intraocular lens may or may not be inserted. After surgery, children may require patching, glasses and/or contact lenses. An intraocular lens may be inserted at that time or in the future when the child reaches an appropriate age. Your child‚Äôs pediatric ophthalmologist can explain the benefits and risks of pediatric cataract surgery in greater detail if the procedure is necessary. ‚ÄúIf there is a known systemic or genetic disease, such as diabetes or Down syndrome, or if there is a family history of childhood or early-onset cataracts, then a yearly eye exam is a good idea,‚Äù Feldman says. ‚ÄúHowever, for most normal kids, the pediatrician will examine the child‚Äôs eyes at each well visit and can refer the patient to a pediatric ophthalmologist if there are abnormalities such as an abnormal red reflex, strabismus, nystagmus or a failed vision screening.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government Pediatric cataracts is one of many conditions treated by the Krieger Eye Institute team. Call 410-601-2020 to learn more about KEI services or make an appointment. You can visit lifebridgehealth.org or call 410-601-WELL for more on other services offered by LifeBridge Health, including specialty care and community events.¬†

headline: Maryland Weather: Flooding Reported Across Region From Heavy Rain
summary: The National Weather Service said multiple rounds of showers and scattered storms are possible of producing heavy rain. The average rainfall amounts of one to two inches are expected.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî¬† A cold front swept sustained, heavy rain into the region Thursday morning, flooding roadways and triggering flood and storm warnings. A flood warning remains in effect for Baltimore City and Howard, Baltimore, and Harford counties until 5 p.m. Cecil County is under a flood warning until 3 p.m. and Carroll and Frederick counties are under flood warnings until 4 p.m. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured The primary threat is damaging winds that could reach speeds of up to 50 miles per hour, according to the Weather Service, which could topple trees and bring down large branches. Average rainfall amounts of one to two inches are expected. Severe weather led  authorities to close public schools in Carroll and Frederick counties . Victory Villa Elementary in Baltimore County was also  closed due to a power outage , though it wasn‚Äôt immediately clear whether that was weather-related. Standing water posed a threat to drivers in parts of Maryland, leading to multiple high-water rescues, some in Harford County and another in Montgomery County.   #mdwx  Just in‚Ä¶A severe thunderstorm warning through 8:45 for Baltimore County.  pic.twitter.com/y63jZJXllW   ‚Äî Marty Bass WJZ (@MartyBassWJZ)  September 23, 2021 Heavy rain falling over increasingly saturated ground may result in flash flooding. Flooding is reported in multiple parts of Maryland.   Heavy rain in downtown Baltimore this morning. Be sure to drive safely today!  @wjz   pic.twitter.com/01toUiPL5l   ‚Äî Rachel Menitoff (@RachelMenitoff)  September 23, 2021   üåßüåßFLASH FLOODING | multiple road closures due to flooding | please avoid traveling if you can and DO NOT attempt to drive through water on the roadways   ‚Äî FrederickCounty Fire (@FCDFRS)  September 23, 2021 READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn In Montgomery County, severe flooding has been reported, closing roads there. One driver had to be rescued from a vehicle after it stalled in high water. Flooding also closed roads in Harford County where first responders were working to  rescue a woman trapped inside a vehicle , according to the Harford Fire Blog.   ICYMI ‚Äì Flash Flood WARNING in effect  @MontgomeryCoMD  ‚Äì ~7a Water Rescue on Beach Dr between Kensington Parkway and Connecticut Ave., driver safely removed from the vehicle that had become stalled in High-water,  @mcfrs  on scene, flash flood  https://t.co/lVA7Q0q9HL   pic.twitter.com/Z1L6DpuUO3   ‚Äî Pete Piringer (@mcfrsPIO)  September 23, 2021 Due to Thursday‚Äôs weather, Frederick County public schools are closed.   Due to inclement weather and road closures in the area, Frederick County Public Schools will be closed Thursday, September 23, 2021. Offices will be opening 2 hours late. headline: Massachusetts State Police Union Asks Judge To Delay Vaccine Mandate For Troopers
summary: The Massachusetts State Police union asked a judge Wednesday to put a hold on Governor Charlie Baker‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine mandate for troopers.
bodytext: BOSTON (CBS) ‚Äì The Massachusetts State Police union asked a judge Wednesday to put a hold on Governor Charlie Baker‚Äôs COVID-19 vaccine mandate for troopers.   A judge heard from attorneys for both the Commonwealth and the State Police Association of Massachusetts in Suffolk Superior Court.   The union, which represents 1,800 members, argues that the state needed to bargain with workers before implementing the mandate, which states that 44,000 executive department employees must show proof of vaccination by October 17 or risk losing their jobs.   They also argued that by putting that deadline in place, it essentially precludes members from getting the two dose Moderna shot, and will shortly rule out the two-dose Pfizer vaccine as well, leaving members with just the Johnson and Johnson vaccine as their only option.   The troopers‚Äô union asked the judge for an injunction to pause the mandate.   The Commonwealth says it did negotiate with the union and that potential penalties for failing to meet the mandate can be ironed out after the deadline.   ‚ÄúThere has to be situations where there is an ability of the government, in an exigency such as the COVID-19 pandemic, to have a deadline of implementation of policy,‚Äù said Jennifer Greaney, an attorney for the Commonwealth.   In general, Boston University health law professor Michael Ulrich says the state has the authority to implement a vaccine a mandate.   ‚ÄúAs we‚Äôve seen, states have broad authority to mandate vaccines in general, but also with state employees. And then, really with police, you have an even stronger argument because, one, they have to be out in public,‚Äù Ulrich said.   The judge did not issue her decision at Wednesday‚Äôs hearing, but said she will make it promptly.   According to the attorney representing the union, roughly 20-percent of State Police employees remain unvaccinated.   The union filed a lawsuit September 17 to get Baker to delay the COVID-19 vaccine mandate.   The union wants members who‚Äôve previously had COVID-19 or who choose not to get the vaccine for either medical, religious, or personal reasons to be able to take a weekly test and wear a mask on the job.   They‚Äôre also requesting that if a member contracts COVID-19, becomes ill from the vaccine, is forced to retire because of coronavirus, or if they were to die, that it be considered a ‚Äúline-of-duty‚Äù injury.   If they‚Äôre not given time to negotiate, the lawsuit argues, it could result in ‚Äúirreparable‚Äù harm to troopers.

headline: Eric Abraham Proud To Represent His Family On Survivor Despite Early Exit: ‚ÄòIt Was A Great Experience, I Just Didn‚Äôt See It Coming‚Äô
summary: Eric Abraham speaks with CBS after his surprise elimination on episode 1 of 'Survivor 41.'
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì  Ready, set, go!  Survivor 41  is only a few hours in and we already have two castaways out of the game. Leading up to this season Jeff Probst described the latest version of  Survivor  as a  monster  and unfortunately for Eric Abraham, he was the monster‚Äôs first victim; followed shortly by 23-year-old  Sara Wilson . CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to Abraham about his  Survivor  preparation and the prospect of returning to the game someday. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Full Survivor 41 Episode One Recap MW-  Hi Abraham, sorry we‚Äôre having this conversation so early in the season but it‚Äôs nice to see you! EA-  [Laughs] I know, good to see you too though, Matt. MW-  Going back to the start when you first stepped foot on the island, you‚Äôre a  Survivor  fan for life, what was that moment like? EA-  It was surreal. I mean, to watch this show throughout the years and actually be there, it‚Äôs almost like you‚Äôre watching yourself. I was like No, I‚Äôm not really here, I‚Äôm still back home. But I was actually on the island about start off one of the greatest adventures that you have no control over.  Survivor  is going to go the way it‚Äôs going to go but I had a blast. MW-  And you got thrown right into it the thick of things with that immunity challenge, what was the hardest part of that for you? EA-  Know what, it‚Äôs just a matter of can I move fast enough? Am I in the right place? Am I doing the right things? Am I drawing attention to myself? Or should I just have fun? I had blast though, ask JD about his two ribs. I had a blast. MW-  [Laughs] When I talk to him I‚Äôll be sure to mention it. What kind of preparation went into getting ready for the island? EA-  So what I did was I went into what I call my ‚Äú Survivor  Lab.‚Äù I would go look at different episodes of  Survivor  and I would physically work out. Like okay, that‚Äôs a stamina thing and I‚Äôll need strength in my arms for this or that. I just kind of looked at it and enjoyed reliving some of the episodes I hadn‚Äôt seen in a while. I looked at some of the challenges that have happened in the past and I was ready. I really put in the work. MW-  Were there any former  Survivor  players in particular you wanted to model your game after? EA-  Well, you know what I like the swagger of Boston Rob because he was like, ‚ÄòI‚Äôm from Boston. I‚Äôm doing what I‚Äôm doing.‚Äô Jane‚Äôs physicality, Jane was like, ‚ÄòLook, I‚Äôm tearing up everything. I‚Äôm here to be physical.‚Äô READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn My game plan was also a little Richard Hatch because that was my very first season watching. He just didn‚Äôt care, he was like, ‚ÄòHey, I‚Äôm Richard and I‚Äôm gonna do what I do.‚Äô I also wanted to build relationships like Rudy and bring different types of people together. I think that‚Äôs what  Survivor  is all about. MW-  That‚Äôs a solid group to take inspiration from. You seemed like a real natural leader out there as well, did you plan on playing things that way or did that just develop based on who you were out there with? EA-  Well, I spent 22 years in the military, so it‚Äôs is there. Do I want to use it, that‚Äôs a different story. [laughs]. That can get you voted off so you kind of walk a fine line. How much of my real personality do I want to show? Am I going to really let them see me? What am I going to hold back? So I wanted to bring everyone together, let‚Äôs all work together and be a team. Let‚Äôs try to stay away from voting and make it more of an inclusive type thing. MW-  Your plan going into tribal was to vote out Tiffany, clearly things didn‚Äôt go that way. What‚Äôs going through your mind when you realize things hadn‚Äôt gone to plan? EA-  It was too late. I had painted Tiffany because Tiffany gave me enough paint to paint away. When we did the first challenge, I was like hey Tiffany didn‚Äôt pull her away. We did the next challenge. When you play  Survivor  you‚Äôve got to get the target off your back, even if there isn‚Äôt a target on your back. You‚Äôve got to get people to say, you know what, I see what what he‚Äôs looking at. Then when I got the votes; I just didn‚Äôt see it coming. MW-  As you reflect on your experience now, what are you going to take away from  Survivor ? EA-  You know what, it‚Äôs twofold in the in the sense that I was out there and not just representing me but my family. I dedicated my show to my mom. She raised three boys and now one of her boys is on one of the top shows on CBS. She just called me and said they cheated me out of the show [laughs] and my mom is 70, she doesn‚Äôt play. Just to have an opportunity to be with this cast this season too, I part of a diverse cast of individuals that lived out a dream that we all had together. It was a great experience. MW-  I think I know the answer this last question, but just to get it on record. If you have the chance to go back out there again are you taking it? EA-  They just showed a snippet of me this season. They didn‚Äôt want to give you a full Abraham experience just yet. They said, you know what, we‚Äôll give you a snippet and next time I‚Äôm on the show. I‚Äôll be there much longer. I‚Äôm coming back.  Survivor  fans, that‚Äôs not the last you‚Äôll see of me! MW-  I‚Äôm looking forward to that. Next time we talk it‚Äôll be much deeper in the season I hope! Thank you so much Abraham been a pleasure talking to you. You did a great job representing yourself and your family out there and hope I see you soon! EA-  Hey, thanks Matt! MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government Tune in for new episodes of  Survivor 41  every Wednesday at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS or streaming with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

keywords: is the covid vaccine safe for pregnant women
is it safe to get vaccinated if you're pregnant
is it safe to get the covid vaccine if you're pregnant
headline: New Study Shows COVID Vaccines Are Safe For Pregnant Women, Also Protect Newborns
summary: "You could possibly be saving two lives with vaccination," Dr. Jennifer Lighter said.
bodytext: NEW YORK (CBSNewYork)  ‚Äî There‚Äôs good news in a study out Wednesday about the safety and effectiveness of the  COVID vaccine  for pregnant women, and especially for their babies. The mRNA vaccines are not only safe for pregnant women, they also protect their newborns. READ MORE:  Ravens Donate 500 Tickets To UMMS To Attend Tonight's Game Against The Colts It has been one of the most worried-over issues in the COVID vaccine debates ‚Äî is the vaccine safe for pregnant women? If so, when should she get the shot? And of course, is the vaccine safe for the unborn baby? We now have answers. As CBS New York‚Äôs Dr. Max Gomez reports, in a study just published in the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology-Maternal Fetal Medicine, NYU researchers measured antibody levels in pregnant women who had been vaccinated and later measured those antibodies in their newborns. ‚ÄúWhen the baby is born, we call it a neonate, and they had not only antibody, but very high levels of antibody, which means that the infant will be protected for several months of life,‚Äù said Dr. Jennifer Lighter, with NYU Langone Health. READ MORE:  It's Too Soon To Declare Victory Against COVID-19 Ahead Of The Holidays, But These Festivities Are Safe To Resume, Experts Say In other words, the antibodies that mom-to-be developed after her vaccination were passed along to her fetus while still in the womb. Importantly, doctors were also able to distinguish between antibodies from the vaccine as opposed to antibodies from a previous  COVID  infection. Bottom line? ‚ÄúVaccination affords protection not only for the mother but for the infant as well that you‚Äôre saving. You could possibly be saving two lives with vaccination,‚Äù Lighter said. MORE NEWS:  What Do You Think About Kids Ages 5 to 11 Getting The COVID-19 Vaccine? Other studies have found that the Pfizer and Moderna vaccines have now been given to more than 160,000 pregnant women with no increase in adverse events, including no premature births above that seen in unvaccinated women. This study found that women made the most antibodies if vaccinated in the second half of their pregnancy.

headline: ‚ÄòSurvivor 41‚Äô Episode 1 Recap: Two Eliminations, One Summit
summary: "Survivors, ready?!" After waiting over a year for another adventurous season, the new age of Survivor is finally here!
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì ¬† ‚ÄúSurvivors, ready?!‚Äù After waiting over a year for another adventurous season, the new age of  Survivor  is finally here! Did you miss the two-hour season premiere last night? Here‚Äôs what went down on the first episode of  Survivor 41 ‚Ä¶   Photo Courtesy of CBS   READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured As  Survivor  has now entered its third decade, this season is already off to a wild start. That‚Äôs right; this new game of  Survivor  is definitely ‚Äúa monster.‚Äù Minimal supplies. No food. Powerful game-changing twists. Oh, and did I mention, the game is now 26 days?! But don‚Äôt be fooled; even though the game is shorter, based on last night‚Äôs episode, this season is moving at an even faster pace. Starting off, it‚Äôs pretty clear that this game is unlike any other season. Right away, host Jeff Probst informs each tribe that they‚Äôll only receive one pot, one machete, and one flint. On top of that, they won‚Äôt have any rice or food source. But before receiving their pot, machete, and flint, they must, of course, compete for it. Between the three new tribes, Luvu, Ua and Yase, it was the Ua tribe who dominated the victory and got to receive their pot, machete, and flint with no repercussions. The other two tribes, on the other hand, were in for a rude awakening‚Ä¶ Meet the Tribes: Luvu Tribe (BLUE)   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Danny McCray, a 33-year-old ex-NFL player from Frisco, TX Deshawn Radden, a 26-year-old medical student from Miami, FL Erika Casupanan, a 31-year-old communications manager from Toronto, Ontario Heather Aldret, a 52-year-old stay-at-home mom from Charleston, SC Naseer Muttalif, a 36-year-old sales manager from Morgan Hill, CA Sydney Segal, a 25-year-old law student from Brooklyn, NY The Luvu tribe didn‚Äôt have the best, nor the worst, first impression on the opening challenge of this episode. Even though they came in second, they were still up for an additional task to get their pot, machete, and flint. This granted task was called ‚ÄúSavvy or Sweat.‚Äù The tribe had to choose two people to complete either a ‚Äúsavvy‚Äù task or ‚Äúsweat‚Äù task ‚Äì a puzzle or a more endurance-based challenge. The Luvu tribe chose Danny and Deshawn to complete the ‚Äúsweat‚Äù task that involved transferring water into a big bucket ‚Äì Survivor-style. If completed in under four hours, they‚Äôd receive their supplies. Since the two castaways had to separate from the tribe right away, Luvu all agreed on the ‚Äúno strategy rule‚Äù until they finished. And well‚Ä¶ that didn‚Äôt last long. While checking on Danny and Deshawn, Naseer thought he saw the two hunting for idols. Naseer immediately scrapped the ‚Äúno strategy‚Äù rule and rushed to tell the tribe what he thought he saw. In just under four hours, Danny and Deshawn finished the savvy task, and, of course, strategy was back on. Sydney was the one who told Deshawn about Naseer being weary about them. It‚Äôs only the first day in, and this tribe‚Äôs strategic game is moving fast. But, will their strategy pay off? Yase Tribe (YELLOW)   Photo Courtesy of CBS   David Voce, a 34-year-old neurosurgeon from Chicago, IL Eric Abraham, a 50-year-old cyber security analyst from San Antonio, TX Evvie Jagoda, a 28-year-old Ph.D. student from Arlington, MA Liana Wallace, a 20-year-old college student from Washington, DC Tiffany Seely, a 47-year-old teacher from Plainview, NY Xander Hastings, a 20-year-old app developer from Chicago, IL Meanwhile, the Yase tribe came in dead last on the opening challenge. Let‚Äôs just say, it was so bad; Probst even said it may have been the ‚Äúbiggest embarrassment for day one in  Survivor  history.‚Äù But, the Yase tribe used this underdog energy to empower them, while keeping a positive attitude by saying their ‚Äúonly way to go is up.‚Äù That is, until they were, too, granted with the ‚ÄúSavvy or Sweat‚Äù task to gain their supplies. On the Yase tribe, both David and Xander got the ‚Äúsweat‚Äù task done, finishing it under the given four hours. We see a lot of gameplay on the Yase tribe as well. An interesting thing about this season, especially showcased through the Yase tribe, is that we‚Äôre learning even more about who these castaways are back at home ‚Äì just like in the old school  Survivor  seasons. Getting to know their backgrounds allows us, viewers at home, to connect with these castaways deeper and get even more invested in their game. I love that about  Survivor ! Ua Tribe (GREEN)   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Brad Reese, a 49-year-old rancher from Shawnee, WY Genie Chen, a 46-year-old grocery clerk from Portland, OR Jairus Robinson, a 20-year-old college student from Oklahoma City, OK Ricard Foy√©, a 31-year-old flight attendant from Sedro-Woolley, WA Sara Wilson, a 23-year-old healthcare consultant from Boston, MA Shantel Smith, a 34-year-old pastor from Washington, DC READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Now, the Ua tribe crushed it in the opening sequence. Since they earned their supplies right away, the tribe didn‚Äôt have to be tasked with any ‚ÄúSavvy or Sweat‚Äù challenge. Instead, we got to see a wide range of what kind of games these castaways were all about playing this season. One stand out on the tribe, JD, who is younger than this show itself, gave a big impression to the tribe right off the bat. Being a super fan himself, it was clear JD had a plan to build his social game from the start. However, this can be risky at the beginning of the game, as it may be a bit obvious. Ricard noticed JD‚Äôs strong and sociable demeanor and began considering him a major game threat. Meanwhile, this episode also highlighted Shantel (Shan), a pastor from DC. From the looks of it, Shan is working with everyone on the social level. She‚Äôs using the ‚Äòpastor image‚Äô to her advantage to gain trust, but she certainly knows she‚Äôs here to make some big, potentially backstabbing moves! Not going to lie; she was a massive stand-out on this episode ‚Äì I‚Äôm impressed with her so far! Survivor  Summit   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Ah yes, as  Survivor 41  is clearly showing, there are more and more twists by the minute. And, by the second day, we were thrown another loop to watch unfold. The ‚Äò Survivor  Summit‚Äô involved each tribe selecting one person to get on this mysterious boat and just straight up ‚Äúfind out what happens.‚Äù Since the tribes were unsure of the outcomes, it wasn‚Äôt straightforward with who should go. After some debating, and even just good ol‚Äô drawing rocks, it was down to Danny from the Luvu, Xander from Yase, and JD from Ua to all be taken to the ‚Äúunknown.‚Äù The three departed individually from their camps and arrived at another island nearby. This nearby island greeted the three selected castaways with a sign that said something along the lines about getting to know one another as they must walk this steep path up a hill. After their hike, the three got to know each other pretty well‚Ä¶ hopefully well enough to make an individual, gut-based decision. That‚Äôs right; these three were up to make yet another,  Survivor  game-changing decision. The decision was simple ‚Äì each of them, individually, must either choose ‚Äúrisk their vote‚Äù or ‚Äúprotect their vote.‚Äù Pretty simple, right? Not so much. The ‚Äúrisk their vote‚Äù option meant they had a chance to receive an extra vote. The ‚Äúprotect their vote‚Äù option means nothing happens. The thing is, these three castaways had to make their decision based on their gut feeling of the other two. If all three castaways chose ‚Äúrisk their vote,‚Äù they‚Äôd all lose their vote at the next tribal council. However, if it‚Äôs a split decision, and just one person chooses ‚Äúprotect their vote,‚Äù and the other two choose ‚Äúrisk their vote,‚Äù then those two people will receive that extra vote advantage. If the two people chose ‚Äúprotect,‚Äù then, in that case, just that one odd person would lose their vote. Given that they do not know what the other castaways will select, this was a difficult decision (and difficult got me to explain, ha). In the end, Danny went back to his tribe honestly and told them he selected ‚Äúprotect.‚Äù While Xander, on the other hand, went back to his tribe honestly and said he chose ‚Äúrisk.‚Äù That left it to JD to indicate which way this advantage or disadvantage would go. JD went to his tribe and shared that he chose ‚Äúprotect.‚Äù Being skeptical, Ricard said behind the scenes that he did not believe JD was telling the truth‚Ä¶ but was Ricard right? Immunity Challenge   Photo Courtesy of CBS   The season premiere Immunity Challenge was a huge opening, literally. Not only was this challenge huge and physically exhausting, but Probst dropped another twist onto these three tribes. This new twist is called the ‚Äúshot in the dark.‚Äù Probst shared how this twist would only be in effect at tribal council. Each castaway would be given a ‚Äúshot in the dark‚Äù dye where they would have the option to drop their dye into a bag, privately in the voting booth, if they felt like their name was on the chopping block. This meant, if you dropped your dye, you would not vote, yet, you would get a one-in-six chance of saving yourself from getting voted out. It‚Äôs literally a ‚Äúshot in the dark‚Äù because who knows what name you may draw out of that bag ‚Äì and chances of pulling your own name are pretty slim. Now, the Immunity Challenge itself was, of course, intricate. So intricate that  Survivor  even dropped a new game for junior players to join in! This is called ‚ÄúThe Game within the Game.‚Äù A puzzle appeared on the episode for a few seconds, encouraging young  Survivor  viewers to visit ‚ÄúSurvivorGwg.com‚Äù to play more. I visited the site, and it‚Äôs a pretty cute add-on for kids this season! Check it out here! After an exhausting series of obstacles, it was down to the final, infamous  Survivor  puzzle between the Ua and Luvu tribes to win it (Yase, again, fell pretty behind). As always, in  Survivor , there‚Äôs no room for mistakes. And, unfortunately for the Ua tribe, it was just that. While they were in the lead, Sara and Shan made a crucial mistake by accidentally keeping one puzzle piece in a bag. This cost them‚Ä¶ big time. Luvu won the first Immunity Challenge, which meant both Ua and Yase must head to a back-to-back Tribal Council. Oh, and I almost forgot to mention ‚Äì these two tribes also had to give up their flint on top of their loss‚Ä¶ yikes. Tribal Council ‚Äì Yase Tribe In this first episode, the Yase tribe had a pretty slow start to the game. At the beginning of the episode, Tiffany, a die-hard  Survivor  fan, didn‚Äôt make the most significant impression on Abraham, who seems to be a natural leader. Abraham was determined to get Tiffany out, as he viewed her as weak right off the bat. However, Tiffany‚Äôs social game was working pretty well during these first few days. It seemed like she aligned herself with the right people. The vote was clearly between the two, but it was Tiffany‚Äôs social game that saved her. This meant Abraham was the first one out of this season of  Survivor 41 , as he felt surprised and ‚Äúblindsided‚Äù while his torch got snuffed. Eric Abraham Castoff Interview   Photo Courtest of CBS   Tribal Council ‚Äì Ua Tribe The Ua tribe was more than ready to cast their votes. But let‚Äôs just say, the actual strategy at tribal council got pretty messy. At first, as viewers, you see that Shan is in the middle. It becomes clear she is the swaying vote ‚Äì and that‚Äôs exactly what she wanted. As Ricard felt threatened by JD‚Äôs social game, he, of course, wanted the young lad voted out first. This left things pretty complicated though because Sara was the other target since she lost the challenge on the puzzle. Things became more and more complicated, as it suddenly became a ‚ÄúLIVE‚Äù tribal council instead. Castaways began whispering to one another from left to right. Tribal was getting heated. As paranoia settled in, the ballots all seemed like they were between either JD, Sara, and at one point, even Brad. This tribal was so chaotic; the castaways even teased the idea of using their ‚Äúshot in the dark‚Äù advantage. In the end, there was no shot in the dark, just one clear vote. Sara was the next person that got voted out on  Survivor season 41 . And, on top of that, in private, both Xander and JD received their ‚Äúextra vote‚Äù advantages from the summit ‚Ä¶which means, was JD lying to his tribe this whole time? Sara Wilson Castoff Interview   Photo Courtesy of CBS   Wow. That‚Äôs really all I can say so far about this season. Just‚Ä¶ wow. There are quite a few intense twists in  Survivor 41  so far ‚Äì did you keep up with them all? In my new  Survivor  Pool , I was given the two castaways, Genie and Abraham. And welp, it looks like my odds of winning are pretty slim now! Who do you predict to win this season? Let me know what you thought of the  Survivor 41  premiere, and tweet me  @mick_cloudy  ! MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government Don‚Äôt miss  Survivor 41 , Wednesdays at 8/7c on CBS, as well as streaming live and on-demand with  Paramount+  or the CBS App!

headline: Sara Wilson Reacts To ‚ÄòWorst Case Scenario‚Äô After Early Survivor Elimination: ‚ÄòGiven Me So Much Fire On The Inside‚Äô
summary: Sara Wilson looks back on her experience after being voted off 'Survivor 41.'
bodytext: (CBS) ‚Äì   Survivor 41  is off to the races and ‚Äú The Monster ‚Äù wasted no time with two eliminations during episode one. For 23-year-old Sara Wilson it was a quick trip to paradise as she was the first member of the Ua tribe voted off following  Eric Abraham ‚Äòs elimination from Yase earlier in the episode. CBS‚Äô Matt Weiss spoke to Wilson about living out a dream getting to the island and the pressures of puzzle building. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Full Survivor 41 Episode One Recap MW-  Hello Sara, I know you‚Äôre probably not happy to talk to me, at least not this early on in the season but it‚Äôs nice to see you! SW-  [Laughs] No it‚Äôs all good, nice to see you too! MW-  You know you did accomplish something that not many people have or ever will just getting on the show. As you look back on your experience how do you feel even making it to the island? SW-  It‚Äôs been a lifelong dream of mine and even though it didn‚Äôt end the way it hoped I think back to the moments of getting the call I made it on, sitting on those boats going to the shore and those are now some of my core top 10 memories; no one can take that away from me regardless of that outcome. Honestly going during COVID too we didn‚Äôt know if it was even going to happen. It could have easily not happened so I‚Äôm just so blessed and thankful to have been a part of it and that we were able to go out there. MW-  When you arrived on the island and took that first step on land what‚Äôs that moment like? SW-  Honestly surreal. I mean I‚Äôm looking at the boat, I‚Äôm looking at Jeff Probst! I‚Äôm like, this is Jeff Probst, that‚Äôs him! I‚Äôm not kidding I couldn‚Äôt believe this was actually happening it‚Äôs so surreal. It was a moment I thought about and was waiting for my whole life and I‚Äôm so happy it happened. MW-  Obviously you‚Äôre a huge fan so you were familiar with the same, how did you prepare? SW-  I‚Äôm a big athlete, I was a water polo player and a swimmer so I really banked on that. I was like if there‚Äôs just one swimming challenge I‚Äôm the girl for it; obviously you didn‚Äôt really get to see me use it so that was sad. The mental preparation was there too though, I felt really solid about my strategies to be honest. I knew how I wanted to play the game and it‚Äôs also really hard to strategize beforehand because so much of it is dependent on the whole cast and who‚Äôs on your tribe. It was also really about mentally preparing myself because I hadn‚Äôt left LA in the entire year of the pandemic. Now all of a sudden I‚Äôm being flown out to Fiji, it was very jarring. I just prepared myself for that and prepared myself for any of the outcomes that could have happened. Going out at the first tribal was like worst case scenario, but I feel like I set myself up nicely to know I can handle this. MW-  I hate to bring this up but clearly the puzzle during the immunity challenge was an issue. There are a lot of people at home who couch quarterback and say ‚Äòif I was there I could have done it‚Äô or ‚Äòhow hard can it really be‚Äô. Now that you‚Äôve been in those shoes, what‚Äôs it like being in that high stress situation and trying to fit all those pieces together? READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn SW-  You know, it felt like it was going well. Chen was emptying and I was putting them in and we had a¬† really good rhythm with it, then all of a sudden it just melted. It‚Äôs hard because I‚Äôm so competitive and there‚Äôs so much pressure with Jeff Probst screaming at you, your teammates are trying to scream at you from behind you and it‚Äôs so hard to stay level headed. For us that one piece was so integral to connect the puzzle, it was a very difficult puzzle. I knew something was wrong and it was just hard to get past that. I feel like. But like you said as someone who is good at puzzles, I‚Äôve definitely watched the show and thought it‚Äôd be easier. When you get out there you realize, oh my gosh, it‚Äôs way harder than it looks I promise you. MW-  And then the chaos didn‚Äôt stop there. You go a live tribal council and everyone is trying to figure out what to do next, what‚Äôs going through your mind as everything is unfolding all around you? SW-  Honestly the live tribal was the best thing that could happen for me because the vote was pretty much locked on me before we went to tribal. I went into that tribal thinking, I‚Äôm 100% going to play my shot in the dark because I don‚Äôt have any other chance. Then I kind of got this idea before tribal I mentioned to Chen and Ricard maybe let‚Äôs do Brad. Brad had put our names out and someone literally tells someone they‚Äôre going home isn‚Äôt someone you can work with in the long term. I was really trying to pitch for it because I felt like that was the only person I had leverage against. Nothing against Brad, I just needed it to be anyone but me. When the whispers were happening, out of the back corner of my eye I saw Chen whisper to Ricard saying Brad. I knew they weren‚Äôt lying to me but I also knew I wasn‚Äôt safe. MW-  When that torch goes out and your time in the game is over did you at least take some solace being that close to Jeff as a big fan? SW-  I didn‚Äôt even like acknowledge him [laughs]. I felt like I was so dazed, honestly I feel like I blacked out. I was just like is this really happening? You don‚Äôt come to  Survivor  to get voted off one the first council, it‚Äôs very disappointing. I was very heartbroken, I was upset, but I knew someone had to go home. I feel like I carried myself with a lot of elegance, a lot of poise and it just is what it is. I‚Äôm still very proud of myself! MW-  I think I know the answer to this already but given the chance, would you go back out there? SW-  Is that even a question?! Of course! [laughs] Going out there and getting voted out early, it sucks but it‚Äôs not the end of my story, it‚Äôs the beginning. It‚Äôs literally given me so much fire on the inside, I am just chomping at the bit to get back out there. MW-  Happy to hear it, you represented yourself very well out there and I‚Äôm sorry the game came to an end so soon but hopefully we‚Äôll see you back out there. Thanks for the time Sara and all the best moving forward! SW-  Thank you so much, you too! MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government Tune in for new episodes of  Survivor 41  every Wednesday at 8:00PM ET/PT on CBS or streaming with  Paramount+ . Check your local listings for more information.

headline: NFL Week 3 AFC North Preview: Ravens ‚ÄòShould Finally Have a Sunday Afternoon Breather,‚Äô Says CBS Baltimore‚Äôs Mark Viviano
summary: The AFC North is shaping up to be extremely competitive, with the Ravens, Bengals,  Browns, and Steelers all splitting their first two games.
bodytext: ( CBS Baltimore ) ‚Äî  The AFC North is shaping up to be extremely competitive, at least in the early weeks of the season. The Baltimore Ravens, Cincinnati Bengals, Cleveland Browns, and Pittsburgh Steelers have all split their first two games The Ravens are coming off a huge win over the Kansas City Chiefs on Sunday night. It was the first time that Lamar Jackson has beat the Chiefs in his young career. The Browns also picked up their first win at home against the Houston Texans. The Bengals and Steelers both lost tough ones. In Week 3, the Bengals head to the Steel City to open the intra-division schedule. It will be a battle of offenses struggling to keep their quarterbacks upright and put their teams back on track. The Browns host the Chicago Bears, with rookie Justin Fields starting under center for the first time. And then the Ravens finally get a break from primetime, when they go out on the road against the Detroit Lions. READ MORE:  Jackson Leads Ravens Back To 31-25 OT Win Over Colts CBS Baltimore sports director Mark Viviano looks at the three AFC North matchups. All times listed are Eastern. Stream your local NFL On CBS game live on Paramount+. Cincinnati Bengals @ Pittsburgh Steelers, Sunday, September 26 @ 1:00 p.m. Ben Roethlisberger comes into the Bengals game with a left pec injury sustained in last week‚Äôs loss to the Las Vegas Raiders. He‚Äôs not the only one  banged up . Outside linebackers T.J. Watt and Alex Highsmith, wide receiver Diontae Johnson and cornerback Joe Haden and inside linebacker Devin Bush also made the growing list. Big Ben‚Äôs injury situation wasn‚Äôt helped by the offensive line play in front of him. The Raiders sacked him twice and knocked him down 10 times. Running back Najee Harris struggled to just 38 yards on 10 carries. The Steelers had just 29 yards as a team. They‚Äôll face a Cincinnati run defense that held David Montgomery to 61 yards on 20 carries last week and Dalvin Cook to the same numbers in the week prior. Bengals quarterback Joe Burrow doesn‚Äôt have much help in front of him either. ‚ÄúPoor Joe Burrow,‚Äù said Viviano. ‚ÄúHe has no offensive line. I mean they‚Äôve invested in a lot of things around him. But plus that, you would think after he got hurt, that would have been a priority for them. Clearly they missed out on that one.‚Äù The Bears sacked Burrow five times in Week 2 and knocked him down plenty more times. The young quarterback didn‚Äôt help his cause either, tossing three picks on three consecutive passes. If Burrow can stay on his feet, he may find Tyler Boyd and Tee Higgins (if he‚Äôs healthy) for some nice gains. The Steelers gave up 382 yards passing and two touchdowns Derek Carr last week. ‚ÄúI think this can be a closer game than you might otherwise think,‚Äù Viviano speculated. ‚ÄúI see the Steelers pulling it out. They‚Äôre at home, they should win this. I see them winning by like six points. But without an offensive line on either side, there‚Äôs a lot of unpredictability going in.‚Äù READ MORE:  Washington Wizards Hold Open Practice At Morgan State University Chicago Bears @ Cleveland Browns, Sunday, September 26 @ 1:00 p.m. The Bears‚Äô Week 3 matchup with the Browns may mark the beginning of the Justin Fields era in Chicago. The rookie will start at quarterback after replacing the injured Andy Dalton in Week 2. A few years ago, the Bears similarly pinned their hopes on the now-gone Mitchell Trubisky. ‚ÄúMitch Trubisky got his first NFL start on the road in the AFC North and beat the Baltimore Ravens in Baltimore,‚Äù Viviano recalled. ‚ÄúAnd in that game, he only threw 16 passes, completed eight of them, only threw for like 100 yards. But their defense won the game. So if you want to use a little history as a possible harbinger of good things for the Bears, you got that.‚Äù The Bears may look to once again follow their defense instead of an inexperienced leader. That unit, led by Khalil Mack, Robert Quinn, and Roquan Smith, made life difficult for Burrow and contained Joe Mixon on the ground last week. The Browns will be without Jarvis Landry, who will miss three games or more with a knee injury. Odell Beckham Jr. could return to the field in Week 3, however. This Cleveland offense is built to run behind Nick Chubb. He has 178 yards and three touchdowns on 6.8 yards per carry in his first two games. And given how many receivers Baker Mayfield threw to last week, the offense has plenty of passing options. Baltimore Ravens vs. Detroit Lions, Sunday, September 26 @ 1:00 p.m. The Ravens finally overcame what quarterback Lamar Jackson has called their ‚Äúkryptonite.‚Äù They beat the Mahomes-led Chiefs. ‚ÄúTo be trailing by 11 points going into the fourth quarter and shut out in Kansas City in that fourth quarter, while scoring two touchdowns, that was something,‚Äù as Viviano tells it. ‚ÄúYou could call it a signature win, but the team will tell you as they‚Äôve been telling us, it only matters if they build on it.‚Äù The Ravens will have their chance to build on it this week in Detroit against the Lions. Baltimore has struggled with injuries early on, losing three running backs for the season. But the running game has still thrived, largely because of Jackson‚Äôs playmaking ability with his feet. He had 86 yards on 12 carries against the Raiders and 107 yards on 16 carries against the Chiefs. Ty‚ÄôSon Williams has also been productive out of the backfield in the first two weeks. The Ravens have seemingly overcome issues along the offensive line. The unit that struggled to slow a Raiders pass rush in Week 1 improved against the Chiefs, leading to about 500 yards of offense. Alejandro Villanueva‚Äôs move to the left tackle in place of Ronnie Stanley was one of the reasons, as Viviano sees it. The Lions have opened the season with two losses to two probable contenders. They allowed 41 points to the 49ers in Week 1 and 35 to the Packers in Week 2. The Ravens will look to continue that trend. But can a Lions offense now led by Jared Goff keep up? The former Ram has 584 passing yards and five touchdowns in his first two outings. The normally stout Ravens defense is giving up the most passing yards per game (376) through the first two games. MORE NEWS:  'It's Monday Night Football': Ravens Fans Gearing Up For Tonight's Game Against The Indianapolis Colts Viviano doesn‚Äôt see it. ‚ÄúThe Ravens should finally, after two primetime games that were just nail-biters, they should finally have a Sunday afternoon breather,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd I see them beating the Lions by a couple of touchdowns. Any given Sunday, but this should be one that the Ravens handle well.‚Äù

headline: Study: Growing Number Of Young People Suffering From Climate Change Anxiety
summary: "It is quite worrying, and it makes me think about our future, and it's definitely not a place that I want my kids to live in,‚Äù one student said.
bodytext: MIAMI ( CBSMiami )  ‚Äì Climate change is among the first things that comes to mind for many when discussing the biggest threats to the future and security of the planet. Now, a new study finds a growing number of young people worldwide are suffering from anxiety about climate change. For the research, 10,000 young adults from 10 countries were asked how they feel about climate change. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúChildren started telling us that they were feeling betrayed and abandoned and they felt that governments were lying about the effectiveness of the action they were taking to address the climate emergency,‚Äù said researcher Caroline Hickman. Researchers from the University of Bath say 84% of 16 to 25 year olds surveyed are at least somewhat worried about climate change. Nearly 60% say they are very or extremely worried about the climate crisis. Seventy-five percent say the future is frightening. ‚ÄúIt is quite worrying, and it makes me think about our future, and it‚Äôs definitely not a place that I want my kids to live in,‚Äù one student told CBS. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the most scary bit really. What‚Äôs g‚Äãonna happen in future generations down the line?‚Äù another concerned student asked. It‚Äôs not just mankind they‚Äôre worried about. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt want them to be left in a world where there‚Äôs no animals that they can look at or there‚Äôs no beautiful things in the world that they can see,‚Äù explained one young adult. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government The climate anxiety study found four in 10 young people around the world are hesitant to have children as a result of the climate crisis. Researchers say the only cure for climate anxiety is governments around the world taking real action to protect the environment.

headline: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Wait Until It‚Äôs Too Late‚Äô: Exhausted Health Professionals Implore Unvaccinated To Get The Shot
summary: "It's been tough," said Michael Gray, a respiratory therapist. "A lot of people are fatigued and worn out. It's a lot to deal with."
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  More than  10,000 Marylanders  are now dead from COVID-19 after a year and a half of exhausting, heart-wrenching, often discouraging work by the doctors, nurses and therapists on the front lines of the battle against the virus. And they are, literally, worn out. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúMy coworkers and across the nation, the nurses, and respiratory therapists, and physicians, everybody across the spectrum they‚Äôre tired and exhausted,‚Äù said Louie Lee, a senior critical care nurse at Shock Trauma. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre mentally broken in a way I don‚Äôt think anybody has had a chance to confront.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been tough,‚Äù said Michael Gray, a respiratory therapist. ‚ÄúA lot of people are fatigued and worn out. It‚Äôs a lot to deal with.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre now seeing people that are young, very young, and don‚Äôt have to die,‚Äù Lee said. Lee and Gray treat the most critically ill Covid patients ‚Äî those already on a ventilator. For a year and a half, they‚Äôve tried to save the lives of those who, if they do survive, will likely have lasting effects from the disease. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúThe sickest of the sick are all unvaccinated. I have not gotten one vaccinated patient who has been near death,‚Äù said Gray. The hardest part, Lee says, is knowing that new deaths could have been prevented. ‚ÄúInitially seeing all the people when there were no vaccines come in and die in front of you, feeling like you can‚Äôt help them was what I think we initially thought was the darkest time,‚Äù said Lee. ‚ÄúBut now that the vaccine is out there and we‚Äôve started to make a break-through and unfortunately back-sliding.‚Äù Gray had simple advice for those who aren‚Äôt yet vaccinated. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt wait until it‚Äôs too late,‚Äù said Gray. ‚ÄúI know a lot of people wish they were vaccinated once they get very sick. Don‚Äôt wait.‚Äù

headline: Maryland Turns To Nursing Students & Out-Of-State Nurses To Shore Up Hospital Workforce
summary: With Maryland‚Äôs hospitals grappling with staffing shortages, Gov. Larry Hogan on Thursday announced the state is taking action to shore up the medical workforce.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  With  Maryland‚Äôs hospitals grappling with staffing shortages , Gov. Larry Hogan on Thursday announced the state is taking action to shore up the medical workforce. As part of the effort, Maryland is removing roadblocks that kept nurses who are licensed in other states from providing nursing care here. Besides that, the state is asking nursing programs to let select nursing students graduate as soon as possible. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúThis week, Maryland reported the nation‚Äôs lowest COVID-19 rate, and we continue to withstand the Delta variant surge better than just about any other state,‚Äù Gov. Hogan said. ‚ÄúWhile our hospitalizations remain well below all of our pandemic surge capacity triggers, we are taking proactive steps to maximize the ability of our hospitals to increase their nursing workforce.‚Äù Moving forward, the Maryland Department of Health will  allow registered nurses and licensed practical nurses who hold active licenses in other jurisdictions to practice in Maryland , a measure backed by the state‚Äôs Board of Nursing. In addition, the Maryland Higher Education Commission is encouraging nursing programs statewide to let qualified nursing students ‚Äúexit early‚Äù and enter the workforce. This can be done either by letting students take exams sooner, streamlining the final weeks of the semester or advancing high-performing students. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúWe want to be clear about what exactly early exit is and is not,‚Äù  MHEC Secretary James Fielder wrote in a letter Thursday to nursing schools‚Äô deans and faculty . ‚ÄúEarly exit is not a change in the curriculum. All learning outcomes, course objectives, and program outcomes must be preserved.‚Äù Dennis Shrader, secretary for the state Department of Health, is also encouraging hospital leadership and schools to collaborate on ways to maximize the use of nursing students and waiving the license requirement for students enrolled in physician assistant students to practice. The goal of these steps, Hogan said, is to give hospitals more flexibility to deal with staffing needs arising from the COVID-19 pandemic. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ‚ÄúWe have worked closely with our hospitals, healthcare associations, and many others in the state on this solution that will further our ability to continue to provide quality care to Marylanders,‚Äù Shrader said. ‚ÄúNurses and student nurses have been invaluable in our fight against COVID-19 and so much more and these steps will ensure that hospitals can use all available nursing solutions.‚Äù

headline: Mountcastle, Hays HRs Help Orioles Beat Skidding Rangers 3-0
summary: Ryan Mountcastle and Austin Hays homered, rookie Zac Lowther pitched five sparkling innings to earn his first major league victory and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Texas Rangers 3-0 Thursday night.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (AP) ‚Äî  Ryan Mountcastle and Austin Hays homered, rookie Zac Lowther pitched five sparkling innings to earn his first major league victory and the Baltimore Orioles beat the Texas Rangers 3-0 Thursday night. After going winless with a 9.61 ERA in his first six appearances, Lowther (1-2) got into a rhythm against the light-hitting Rangers in this matchup of last-place teams. Lowther allowed three hits and notched a career-high seven strikeouts in his finest outing as a big leaguer. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Tyler Wells worked the ninth to complete the five-hitter and earn his fourth save. Mountcastle hit a solo shot in the fifth inning off Glenn Otto (0-3) for a 2-0 lead. Mountcastle earlier this month set the Orioles record for home runs by a rookie ‚Äî eclipsing the 28 by Cal Ripken Jr. in 1982 ‚Äî and leads the team with 31 homers and 84 RBIs. Hays went deep in the eighth, his 22nd homer of the season and eighth in September. The Orioles still own the worst record in the AL (49-104), but this was a nice start to the final homestand of a difficult season that featured a 19-game losing streak and an alarming inability to win at Camden Yards, where they‚Äôre 24-51. It‚Äôs been a struggle for the Rangers, too. Texas (55-98) has lost five straight and eight of nine, and appears a good bet to finish with its first 100-loss season since 1973. This would be only the third time the Rangers reached triple-digit defeats since the franchise moved from Washington in 1972. Otto gave up two runs and five hits with seven strikeouts in five innings. It was his fifth start since coming to Texas in the July 29 trade that sent Joey Gallo to the Yankees. K TIME Lowther and Otto entered with no wins between them, and each had an ERA in excess of 9. Yet, both struck out the side in the first inning, and Lowther set a new career high with two more strikeouts in the second. Not to be outdone, Otto also fanned two batters in the bottom half. ROOKIE RACE Two of the leading candidates for AL Rookie of the Year honors are participating in this four-game series. Texas OF Adolis Garcia came in batting .243 with 30 HRs, 83 RBIs. In addition, his 14 assists were second-most among big league outfielders. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Mountcastle was at .258, and his homer put him ahead of Garcia in homers and RBIs. Tampa Bay OF Randy Arozarena (.271, 19, 65) has the advantage of playing for a first-place club, but Texas manager Chris Woodward believes Garcia‚Äôs defense is the difference-maker. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs made big-time plays time and time again in big moments,‚Äù Woodward said. ‚ÄúThat should be worth a little bit more.‚Äù Garcia is more interested in finishing strong than garnering votes from baseball writers. ‚ÄúThose are things I can‚Äôt control,‚Äù he said through an interpreter. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm just trying to get things done on the field.‚Äù TRAINER‚ÄôS ROOM Orioles: INF Ram√≥n Urias is done for the season after being placed on the 10-day IL on Wednesday with a right adductor strain. ‚Ä¶ OF Anthony Santander (hamstring) is a ‚Äúday or two away‚Äù from returning and is ‚Äúgoing to be sore probably for the rest of the year,‚Äù manager Brandon Hyde said. UP NEXT Rangers: Right-hander Spencer Howard (0-4, 6.86 ERA) tries again to get into the win column on Friday night. It will be his 14th start and 18th appearance in 2021. Orioles: Rookie left-hander Alexander Wells (1-3, 7.96) strives for his first victory since winning in relief on June 29 at Houston. ___ MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government (¬© Copyright 2021 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)

headline: Howard County Seeking Community Feedback On How To Utilize American Rescue Plan Funding
summary: Howard County leaders are looking for the public‚Äôs input on how it should spend money it got from the American Rescue Plan.
bodytext: ELLICOTT CITY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Howard County leaders are looking for the public‚Äôs input on how it should spend money it got from the American Rescue Plan. The America Rescue Plan gives out federal stimulus money to help communities recover from the pandemic. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured Howard County received $63.2 million from the American Rescue Plan. County leaders have opened up an online survey to get its resident‚Äôs opinions on how the money should be spent. ‚ÄúTake the time, fill out the survey, participate in all of the dates that the county executive laid out if you want your feelings heard,‚Äù Howard County RISE Collaborative Chair Ken Ulman said. Some of the money has already been set aside: $5 million will go to hazard pay for essential workers. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn $1.6 million will go toward police body cameras and $2 million will be used for foreclosure assistance. In April, Howard County leaders started using county money to help those facing foreclosure. They spent $1.2 million to help 52 households and there are more applicants waiting in line. ‚ÄúWe are trying to help homeowners retain the equity in their home that they‚Äôve worked so hard build and also stay in their homes with their families and their children,‚Äù¬†Department of Housing and Community Development Director Kelly Cimino said. The survey is open now. On Sept.¬†29 there will be a public hearing for more input. After that, several stakeholder meetings will be held next month before a presentation will be made to the Howard County Council about how the money should be spent on Nov. 3. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ‚ÄúOn a local level, we‚Äôre going to have to continue stepping up to make sure that while hope is on the horizon, we stay on this road to recovery and that people not only survive but get to the other side of this and thrive,‚Äù Howard County Executive Calvin Ball said.

headline: WJZ Presents ‚ÄòA Talk About Race,‚Äô A Town Hall On Race Relations
summary: Hosted by anchors Vic Carter and Rick Ritter, this town hall brings together a panel of community leaders for a candid conversation about race and its impact on our daily lives.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  With the unrest that has unfolded over the past year, race relations is a topic that has been top of mind for many Americans, including the Baltimore community. Here at WJZ, we wanted to address this issue head-on. That‚Äôs why Vic Carter and Rick Ritter hosted ‚ÄúA Talk About Race,‚Äù a half-hour town hall that brought together people from all walks of life to discuss where we‚Äôve been, where we stand and where we go from here. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured For Baltimore, it‚Äôs an issue that hits close to home after the in-custody death of Freddie Gray in 2015. And while his death has resulted in changes within the Baltimore Police Department, many people feel strongly there is more work to be done. So, during the town hall, we tackled the uncomfortable questions.  How can we confront institutionalized racism? What can we do to improve police-community relations? What do meaningful progress and change look like? The goal was to reckon with our past and come up with solutions for the future. But we couldn‚Äôt do it alone ‚Äî we invited five panelists with different perspectives to share their thoughts. The Voices   Bishop Antonio Palmer with the United Black Clergy of Anne Arundel County;   John Wesley, spokesman for Baltimore‚Äôs Office of Equity and Civil Rights;   Adam Jackson, CEO of Leaders of a Beautiful Struggle;   Ericka Alston, CEO of ACCESS Granted;   Retired Sgt. James Spearman with the Annapolis Police Department.   In Their Own Words Below are a handful of thoughts our panelists shared during the town hall. To watch the complete discussion, click play on the video player above. Spearman:  ‚ÄúOne of the things that I always say is that no law enforcement agency, no matter how good they are, if they don‚Äôt have the support and trust of the people, they‚Äôre just an occupying force and nothing ever gets done. There‚Äôs a lot of work that needs to be done in the community, but there‚Äôs also a lot of work that needs to be done within law enforcement.‚Äù READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Alston:  ‚ÄúMy most heartbreaking experience comes from asking a young person, ‚ÄòWhat do you want to be when you grow up?‚Äô ‚ÄòGrow up, I‚Äôm trying to make it to tomorrow.‚Äô That‚Äôs our reality. Our young people are hopeless. There is no evidence around them that outside of those that live in their home, that someone cares about them. If they‚Äôre in a school system designed to fail, they‚Äôre intentionally and strategically placed in a pipeline to prison. ‚Ä¶ Our young people need to be seen, heard, respected and invested in.‚Äù Jackson:  ‚ÄúWhen you have a structural problem, it requires and necessitates a structural response. And that takes time because all we‚Äôve gotten is the opposite for many years. And Baltimore is a city that has suffered from system disinvestment over decades and generations. And I think what people want to see, like for me, it would be to go down to Penn North and to see all the buildings renovated and to see people happy and safe.‚Äù Wesley:  ‚ÄúWe have to find a way to help the officers. The community has to find a way to help these officers spend more time in these communities when they are not there for enforcement. You know, we expect them for enforcement. But we don‚Äôt expect them to do things things like, you know, I used to speak at schools and I‚Äôd ask kids, ‚ÄòWhat do you want to be?‚Äô When the Officer Friendly programs are out there, inadvertently all the boys said, ‚ÄòI want to be a fireman. I want to be a policeman. That is no longer the answer. Nobody wants to be a policeman. I think that speaks volumes.‚Äù Palmer:  ‚ÄúIf you don‚Äôt believe that Jesus had melanin in his skin and you believe that everybody else that looks like me are cursed people, then you‚Äôre going to continue to endure privilege, you‚Äôre going to continue to allow injustices to take place and be silent about it, you‚Äôre going to continue to allow a police officer to commit brutality and fatality and so forth without saying a word. And your congregations of thousands of white folks are going to follow suit. But if you lift up your voice ‚Äî if a Franklin Graham, who has a national platform, will stand besides a TD Jakes and say, ‚Äòtogether we fight‚Äô and ‚Äòtogether we‚Äôve had enough of this‚Äô ‚Äî it‚Äôll start turning around.‚Äù More From ‚ÄòA Talk About Race‚Äô Here‚Äôs some of the conversation that didn‚Äôt make it into the half-hour special:   In Case You Missed It MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government If you weren‚Äôt able to tune in Thursday evening, we‚Äôll be re-airing ‚ÄòA Talk About Race‚Äô on CBSN Baltimore. Below you‚Äôll find a programming schedule:   6:30 p.m. Friday   8 a.m. Saturday   9 a.m. Sunday

headline: CDC Advisory Panel Backs FDA Decision For COVID-19 Booster Shots, Baltimoreans React
summary: COVID-19 booster shots are approved for select, high-risk Americans and the CDC Advisory Panel backs the decision.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  COVID-19 booster shots are approved for select, high-risk Americans and the CDC Advisory Panel backs the decision. It is now up to the CDC to determine when and how they will be distributed. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured The FDA granted emergency use authorization of Pfizer‚Äôs vaccine to older adults and others with high-risk factors Wednesday evening. ‚ÄúMe, at 65, I‚Äôm just being careful, watching where I go and who I surround myself with,‚Äù said Angelo Depasquale of Baltimore. Angelo Depasquale said he still hasn‚Äôt been vaccinated. ‚ÄúYes, it‚Äôs getting there. and, I‚Äôm getting pressure through the family, if you know what I mean,‚Äù Despasquale told WJZ. He said he‚Äôs close to getting the vaccine. He‚Äôs 65 now and peers his age will soon be able to get booster shots of the Pfizer vaccine. ‚ÄúIf that‚Äôs what Pfizer and the FDA and the CDC think is needed, then I‚Äôm all for it,‚Äù said Savannah Runner of Baltimore. ‚ÄúI think if the booster will help people with weakened immune systems, I think that is great,‚Äù Barbara Mars added. The FDA authorized the Pfizer boosters to those 65 and older, adults with compromised immune systems and those whose job or living situation frequently exposes them to the virus. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn The vaccines would be administered at least six months after the second dose. ‚ÄúBecause I work with kids, I probably will end up doing it [getting a booster] because it‚Äôs affecting them now these days,‚Äù said Mars. ‚ÄúIt kind of reinforces to me it‚Äôs not ending anytime soon,‚Äù said Rumer. A CDC panel officially approved those Pfizer booster shots Thursday afternoon. ‚ÄúLike you, I‚Äôm approaching this decision with an interest in doing what‚Äôs right for the public health,‚Äù said Dr. Rochelle Walensky, CDC Director. Rumer is fresh off her first shot and she hopes the unvaccinated family sees the data and follows suit. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping that soon they will change their minds. That‚Äôs part of the reason I got mine was to protect them because I know they‚Äôre not going to do it themselves,‚Äù Rumer said. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government The FDA is expected to consider boosters for the Moderna and Johnson and Johnson vaccines soon.

headline: Harford County Family Raises Over $500K For Fight Against Cancer

bodytext: HARFORD COUNTY, Md. (WJZ) ‚Äî  Sandi and Steve Linkous, along with their two sons Joel and Jacob, are shaving their heads and raising funds in support of those battling childhood cancer. ‚ÄúWe wanted to find a way that we could really make a meaningful connection and have a lasting legacy by actually shaving our heads,‚Äù Steve Linkous said. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured The couple is part of the NAMIC team, which stands for National Association of Mutual Insurance Companies. This year alone, the Linkous family raised more than $400,000, making them the highest raising volunteers to date. All of the proceeds go directly to the St. Baldrick‚Äôs Foundation, a nonprofit organization devoted to raising money to find cures for childhood cancer. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúMost of the resources aligned behind cancer research go to adult cancer research not pediatric,‚Äù said Kathleen Ruddy, chief executive officer of St. Baldrick‚Äôs. The group couldn‚Äôt do its charitable work alone. That‚Äôs why it relies on the efforts of trusty volunteers. ‚ÄúThey may not be a scientist who can find a cure in a laboratory, but they can fuel the work of the scientists and that‚Äôs just as important to a child‚Äôs survival,‚Äù Ruddy said. For the Linkous family, they‚Äôve been inspired year after year by the stories of young cancer survivors and their resilient families. MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government ‚ÄúBeing able to raise these funds to give these children a chance and give those families hope, that‚Äôs what really means something special to us,‚Äù said Linkous.

headline: Baltimore Community Rowing Receives Grant to Get More Student-Athletes of Color Involved
summary: A rowing club in Baltimore¬†has been selected to receive a grant to help student-athletes of color get involved¬†in the sport.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A rowing club in Baltimore¬† has been selected to receive a grant t o help student-athletes of color get  involved ¬†in the sport.   ¬† ‚Äú R owing has typically been a very white, prep school sport ,‚Äù said Karyn Shackelford,¬† the e xecutive¬† d irector of ¬†the club, ¬†Baltimore Community Rowing. ‚Äú It is something that has not really reflected a lot of the communities in which boa t houses reside.‚Äù ¬†         The club is receiving $24,000 and new rowing equipment from the ¬† A ¬†Most Beautiful Thing ¬†I nclusion Fund ,¬† inspired by the book and movie A Most Beautiful Thing, which tells the story of¬† A merica‚Äôs first all ‚Äì black high school rowing team in¬† C hicago. ¬†         ‚ÄúThe Most Beautiful Thing Inclusion Fund is  a ¬†organization that focuses on giving access and opportunity to young kids in underserved communities through the sport of rowing,‚Äù said Arshay Cooper, who wrote the book ¬†and serves as the Inclusion Director for the grant program.     The funding will pay for coaches of color, transportation, swimming lessons, a cademic services and¬† competition ¬†for students.       The rowing racing shell manufacturer Hudson Boat Works and rowing machine company Concept2 are proving two¬† boats, oars and 10 ergometers to the Baltimore rowing club for its middle and high school program. ¬†       ‚ÄúG etting ¬†these boats really widens how many people we can take in and how many people we can teach to row ,‚Äù said J aiden¬† G omez , a coach for the program. ¬†   Cooper  told WJZ that¬† rowing can help students who come from underserved communities grow, be successful and even heal. ¬†       ‚Äú I t reduces trauma right that you may see every ¬† day in your life. The peace that you feel on the water it calms the storms that you go through ,‚Äù he said. ¬† ‚ÄúT he lessons you learn from the sport completely change your life.‚Äù ¬†   If you or your child are interested in getting involved in rowing at Baltimore Community Rowing, visit  baltimorerowing .org. ¬†

headline: Baltimore Man Charged With Murder In Fatal Shooting
summary: Craig Carter, 32, was arrested Wednesday for the shooting death of 40-year-old Ronald White.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A Baltimore man is charged with first- and second-degree murder in a May shooting in south Baltimore, police said.   Craig Carter, 32, was arrested Wednesday for the shooting death of 40-year-old Ronald White.   Officers responded midday on May 17 to the 200 block of Harmison Street, where they found White shot multiple times. He was transported to Shock Trauma, where he later died.   After examining evidence and interviewing witnesses, investigators identified Carter as a suspect. He is being held in Central Booking without bail until his trial, police said.

headline: Injury-plagued Ravens Still Running Through Opponents
summary: A couple of weeks ago, Baltimore's running back group was decimated by injuries, and the team was quickly collecting available veterans in an effort to fill its many holes.
bodytext: OWINGS MILLS, Md. (AP)  ‚Äî The Baltimore Ravens needed another yard to secure their victory over Kansas City. By that point, they had every reason to feel confident. READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured ‚ÄúWe have to have an array of things throughout the season to have ready for those situations,‚Äù offensive coordinator Greg Roman said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs interesting. Whatever plays we run in the game, there‚Äôs also a lot, lot, lot, lot more that we didn‚Äôt run. Things for that type of situation, the players are working on that stuff every week.‚Äù Lamar Jackson picked up the first down on that final fourth-and-1, and the Ravens finished with 251 yards rushing in¬† their 36-35 victory ¬†over the Chiefs last weekend. A couple of weeks ago, Baltimore‚Äôs running back group was decimated by injuries, and the team was quickly collecting available veterans in an effort to fill its many holes. Now, the Ravens are right where they‚Äôve been at the end of each of the past two seasons ‚Äî ranked No. 1 in the NFL in rushing. ‚ÄúWe made a lot of progress last week with all the new guys that are here. We were able to clean up some things,‚Äù Roman said Thursday. ‚ÄúCredit to our offensive staff (and) all the position coaches.‚Äù The Ravens lost J.K. Dobbins and Gus Edwards for the season before it even started. Although running backs sometimes seem interchangeable these days, Baltimore needed a significant overhaul at the position without much time to pull it off. Ty‚ÄôSon Williams had no NFL carries to his credit, and newcomers Latavius Murray, Devonta Freeman and Le‚ÄôVeon Bell were just arriving. ‚ÄúI think if you look back maybe even a few years ago, and to think if we were all in the same room, it would be a cap problem or something like that, right?‚Äù Murray said. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn Through two games, the Ravens have averaged 220 yards on the ground. They‚Äôve extended their streak of 100-yard rushing games to 41, two shy of the league record. Baltimore‚Äôs top rusher is its quarterback, and it helps that Jackson has been healthy ‚Äî although he did miss practice Thursday because of an illness. Jackson rushed for more than 1,000 yards each of the past two seasons, and he‚Äôs at 193 so far in 2021. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a dynamic player who has rare ability, rare talent, and he touches the ball 67 times a game, 70 times a game,‚Äù said Detroit coach Dan Campbell, whose team hosts Baltimore this weekend. ‚ÄúLook, you play the odds, you do everything you can to limit their explosives, but inevitably, even as good as you can play, you look, they rush for 100 yards, what is it, 41 consecutive times? That‚Äôs what they do.‚Äù Williams is Baltimore‚Äôs leading rusher aside from Jackson. He‚Äôs run for 142 yards on 22 attempts ‚Äî 6.5 yards per carry. Murray has 64 yards on 19 carries with a couple of touchdowns. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot of ways that we can hurt you, and again, it starts with Lamar just being beside you,‚Äù Murray said. ‚ÄúNot knowing if he‚Äôs going to keep it or give it, that right there is just difficult in itself. Then with all the different things that we‚Äôre doing, coming at you north and south and then getting the ball outside, it‚Äôs just tough on the defense.‚Äù Freeman has only two carries this season, but one of them went for 31 yards. Bell has been on the practice squad. So the Ravens still have other options they can turn to ‚Äî and more wrinkles they can add. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a lot that goes into this, and you try to choose wisely on game day,‚Äù Roman said. ‚ÄúI think we ran 36 different runs in that game, completely different runs, and I promise you, we had a lot more on the shelf.‚Äù NOTES: WR Marquise Brown (ankle), S DeShon Elliott (concussion), T Ronnie Stanley (ankle) and DE Derek Wolfe (hip/back) did not practice Thursday either. headline: Fort Meade Debunks False Alarm About ‚ÄòActive Shooter‚Äô
summary: A communications mix-up between Fort Meade and media outlets inadvertently triggered a false alarm about an active shooter Thursday at the U.S. military installation.
bodytext: BALTIMORE (WJZ) ‚Äî  A mix-up between Fort Meade and media outlets inadvertently triggered a false alarm about an active shooter Thursday at the U.S. military installation. Authorities at the installation in Anne Arundel County held an annual training exercise Thursday morning to test the garrison‚Äôs readiness for an emergency. But even though the drill was publicized in advance, a tabloid following up on the activity published a report stating that a gunman had opened fire at Fort Meade, resulting in ‚Äúmultiple casualties.‚Äù READ MORE:  'He's An Extremely Lucky Individual': Home Explosion In Edgewood Leaves Man Seriously Injured In a news release distributed hours later, public affairs staff chalked up the confusion to a misunderstanding between the installation and media that were believed to be part of the exercise. READ MORE:  Robbery Suspect Found Dead After Shootout With Police In Woodlawn ‚ÄúFort Meade routinely practices how it would report incidents to media during its exercises. Today‚Äôs incident was an unfortunate miscommunication between the installation and a few media outlets believed to be notional,‚Äù Chad Jones, a spokesperson for Fort Meade, said. ‚ÄúI apologize for the confusion.‚Äù MORE NEWS:  Annapolis Couple Accused Of Trying To Sell Military Secrets To Foreign Government The release stated that even though the public was notified of the training exercise beforehand, Fort Meade‚Äôs public affairs office would ‚Äúuse this unfortunate incident to ensure it is better prepared in case a real-world incident does arise.‚Äù   ‚Ä¶There will be minimal impact to garrison services. Expect to hear ‚ÄúALERT! / Giant Voice messaging!‚Äù and expect ‚Äúchanges to FPCON status‚Äù to happen throughout the exercise‚Ä¶   ‚Äî Fort Meade PAO (@FtMeadeMD)  September 14, 2021
